description: Can epigenetics underlie the enduring effects of a mother's love? Lizzie Buchen investigates the criticisms of a landmark study and the controversial field to which it gave birth.
title: Neuroscience: In their nurture

author: Corie Lok
description: The US National Nanotechnology Initiative has spent billions of dollars on submicroscopic science in its first 10 years. Corie Lok finds out where the money went and what the initiative plans to do next.
title: Nanotechnology: Small wonders

author: Amanda Mascarelli
description: When oil stopped gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, the ecosystems under assault started on a long road to recovery. Amanda Mascarelli meets the researchers assessing their chances.
title: Deepwater Horizon: After the oil

author: David Cyranoski
description: Stymied in the search for genes underlying human neuropsychiatric diseases, some researchers are looking to dogs instead. David Cyranoski meets the geneticist's new best friend.
title: Genetics: Pet project

author: Alla Katsnelson
description: The skeleton may provide more than just structural support. Alla Katsnelson investigates the rise of bone as a metabolic regulator.
title: Physiology: The bones of contention

author: Brian Vastag
description: Researchers have rallied round a promising molecule for rescuing dying nerves. But getting it into the brain remains a daunting challenge, finds Brian Vastag.
title: Biotechnology: Crossing the barrier

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Having taken on the biggest job in biomedicine — leading the US National Institutes of Health — Francis Collins must now help his agency over a funding cliff. Meredith Wadman looks at his record so far, and his plans to cushion the fall.
title: Francis Collins: One year at the helm

author: Virginia Gewin
description: Every summer for the past nine years, water with lethally low concentrations of oxygen has appeared off the Oregon coast. The hypoxia may be a sign of things to come elsewhere, finds Virginia Gewin.
title: Oceanography: Dead in the water

author: Eric Hand
description: Networks of human minds are taking citizen science to a new level, reports Eric Hand.
title: Citizen science: People power

author: Mark Schrope
description: Vernon Asper was one of the first researchers in the Gulf of Mexico to study the oil gushing out from the BP well. But it has not all been smooth sailing, reports Mark Schrope.
title: Deepwater Horizon: A scientist at the centre of the spill

author: Virginia Gewin
description: Plant breeders are turning their attention to roots to increase yields without causing environmental damage. Virginia Gewin unearths some promising subterranean strategies.
title: Food: An underground revolution

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: With its plentiful sun, water and land, Brazil is quickly surpassing other countries in food production and exports. But can it continue to make agricultural gains without destroying the Amazon? Jeff Tollefson reports from Brazil.
title: Food: The global farm

author: Natasha Gilbert
description: Feeding the world is going to require the scientific and financial muscle of agricultural biotechnology companies. Natasha Gilbert asks whether they're up to the task.
title: Food: Inside the hothouses of industry

author: Eric Hand
description: NASA and Germany have spent 15 years and billions of dollars on SOFIA, an airborne telescope that is about to produce its first results. Eric Hand asks whether the science will justify the cost.
title: Astronomy: Ready for boarding — finally

author: Janet Fang
description: Eradicating any organism would have serious consequences for ecosystems — wouldn't it? Not when it comes to mosquitoes, finds Janet Fang.
title: Ecology: A world without mosquitoes

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: A new class of materials is poised to take condensed-matter physics by storm. Geoff Brumfiel looks at what is making topological insulators all the rage.
title: Topological insulators: Star material

author: Naomi Lubick
description: An imminent swarm of tiny quakes beneath western North America could help seismologists prepare for a big one — but only if they can learn to interpret the tremors, finds Naomi Lubick.
title: Seismology: The secret chatter of giant faults

author: Laura Spinney
description: A once-threatened population of African fish is now providing a view of evolution in action. Laura Spinney asks what Lake Victoria cichlids have revealed about speciation.
title: Evolution: Dreampond revisited

author: Rex Dalton
description: Finds in Turkey could answer key questions about ancient human origins, but palaeoanthropologists there must first bury their disputes. Rex Dalton reports from the field.
title: Palaeoanthropology: Disputed ground

author: Erik Vance
description: When emergencies happen in remote settings, field researchers can be left with little recourse. Erik Vance meets a man trying to change that.
title: Profile: The field medic

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: Many climate researchers worry that scepticism about global warming is on the rise. Jeff Tollefson investigates the basis for that concern and what scientists are doing about it.
title: Climate science: An erosion of trust?

author: Colin Macilwain
description: The grandfather of scientific national academies is staging major celebrations this week for its 350th birthday. But, like similar elite groups around the world, Britain's Royal Society has had to work hard to stay relevant and influential, reports Colin Macilwain.
title: Scientific Academies: In the best company

author: Richard Van Noorden
description: Scientific performance indicators are proliferating — leading researchers to ask afresh what they are measuring and why. Richard Van Noorden surveys the rapidly evolving ecosystem.
title: Metrics: A profusion of measures

author: Naomi Lubick
description: With chytrid fungus rapidly spreading around the world, researchers are testing an extreme approach to saving endangered amphibian populations. Naomi Lubick reports from a rescue site.
title: Ecology: Emergency medicine for frogs

author: Colin Macilwain
description: Spending on science is one of the best ways to generate jobs and economic growth, say research advocates. But as Colin Macilwain reports, the evidence behind such claims is patchy.
title: Science economics: What science is really worth

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: The Icelandic eruption has given researchers the opportunity of a lifetime. Katharine Sanderson talks to scientists working around the clock to study the volcano and its effects.
title: Volcanology: Out of the ashes

author: Mark Schrope
description: New England fishermen have mixed feelings about a programme designed to allow overfished species to recover. Mark Schrope reports on how catch shares have scientists fishing for answers.
title: Fisheries: What's the catch?

author: Corie Lok
description: The US National Science Foundation's insistence that every research project addresses 'broader impacts' leaves many researchers baffled. Corie Lok takes a looks at the system.
title: Science funding: Science for the masses

author: Sharon Weinberger
description: Can the science of deception detection help to catch terrorists? Sharon Weinberger takes a close look at the evidence for it.
title: Airport security: Intent to deceive?

author: Alison Abbott
description: Studying primates is the only way to understand human cognition — or so neuroscientists thought. But there may be much to learn from rats and mice, finds Alison Abbott.
title: Neuroscience: The rat pack

author: Jane Qiu
description: When a submarine volcano erupts, the results can be devastating — and fascinating. Jane Qiu finds new drama in underwater biogeography.
title: Oceanography: Death and rebirth in the deep

author: Meredith Wadman
description: In February, a biologist gunned down three colleagues at the University of Alabama, Huntsville. Meredith Wadman reports how their department is trying to move past the tragedy.
title: Universities: Life after death

author: Roff Smith
description: Fifty years ago this month, a massive earthquake in Chile broke new ground in seismic science. Roff Smith looks back at the largest quake ever recorded.
title: Seismology: The biggest one

author: Lizzie Buchen
description: Systems neuroscientists are pushing aside their electrophysiology rigs to make room for the tools of 'optogenetics'. Lizzie Buchen reports from a field in the process of reinvention.
title: Neuroscience: Illuminating the brain

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: Hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles, largely forgotten as attention turned to biofuels and batteries, are staging a comeback. Jeff Tollefson investigates.
title: Hydrogen vehicles: Fuel of the future?

author: Jeffrey Perkel
description: Many scientists want to keep their data and resources free; cybersecurity specialists want them under lock and key. Jeffrey Perkel reports.
title: Cybersecurity: How safe are your data?

author: Josie Glausiusz
description: A conduit from the Red Sea could restore the disappearing Dead Sea and slake the region's thirst. But such a massive engineering project could have untold effects, reports Josie Glausiusz.
title: Environmental Science: New life for the Dead Sea?

author: Brendan Borrell
description: After years of wrangling over the chemical's toxicity, researchers are charting a new way forwards. Brendan Borrell investigates how the debate has reshaped environmental-health studies.
title: Toxicology: The big test for bisphenol A

author: Heidi Ledford
description: Databases could soon be flooded with genome sequences from 25,000 tumours. Heidi Ledford looks at the obstacles researchers face as they search for meaning in the data.
title: Big science: The cancer genome challenge

author: Matt Ford
description: The explosion in commercial archaeology has brought a flood of information. The problem now is figuring out how to find and use this unpublished literature, reports Matt Ford.
title: Archaeology: Hidden treasure

author: Jim Schnabel
description: Almost every human protein has segments that can form amyloids, the sticky aggregates known for their role in disease. Yet cells have evolved some elaborate defences, finds Jim Schnabel.
title: Protein folding: The dark side of proteins

author: Alison Abbott
description: What was it like to participate in the fastest, fiercest research race in biology? Alison Abbott talks to some of the genome competitors about the rivalries and obstacles they faced then — and now.
title: Human genome at ten: The human race

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: The more biologists look, the more complexity there seems to be. Erika Check Hayden asks if there's a way to make life simpler.
title: Human genome at ten: Life is complicated

author: Heidi Ledford
description: Questions about a laboratory assay are making Sirtris, a high-profile biotechnology company, the talking point of the ageing field. Heidi Ledford investigates.
title: Ageing: Much ado about ageing

author: Zeeya Merali
description: Social scientists have embedded themselves at CERN to study the world's biggest research collaboration. Zeeya Merali reports on a 10,000-person physics project.
title: Physics: The Large Human Collider

author: Natasha Gilbert
description: It may be the gold standard of forensic science, but questions are now being raised about DNA identification from ever-smaller human traces. Natasha Gilbert asks how low can you go?
title: Science in court: DNA's identity crisis

author: Laura Spinney
description: A single incriminating fingerprint can land someone in jail. But, Laura Spinney finds, there is little empirical basis for such decisions.
title: Science in court: The fine print

author: Virginia Hughes
description: Last year, functional magnetic resonance imaging made its debut in court. Virginia Hughes asks whether the technique is ready to weigh in on the fate of murderers.
title: Science in court: Head case

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: With the launch of a powerful laser facility, Britain's most secretive lab is opening up to academics. Geoff Brumfiel secures a preview.
title: Nuclear weapons physics: Welcome to the Atomic Weapons Establishment

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: Chemists looking to create complex self-assembling nanostructures are turning to DNA. Katharine Sanderson looks at the science beneath the fold.
title: Bioengineering: What to make with DNA origami

author: Sharon Weinberger
description: Georgia's borders are guarded by some of the best radiation detectors available — so why are nuclear smugglers still slipping through? Sharon Weinberger reports.
title: Non-proliferation: Borderline detection

author: David Cyranoski
description: The bold ambitions of one institute could make China the world leader in genome sequencing. David Cyranoski asks if its science will survive the industrial ramp-up.
title: Chinese bioscience: The sequence factory

author: Olive Heffernan
description: A new generation of sophisticated Earth models is gearing up for its first major test. But added complexity may lead to greater uncertainty about the future climate, finds Olive Heffernan.
title: Earth science: The climate machine

author: Tanguy Chouard
description: Experiments have revealed how single mutations can have huge effects that drive evolution. But small steps pave the way, finds Tanguy Chouard.
title: Evolution: Revenge of the hopeful monster

author: Michael Cherry
description: The release of Nelson Mandela sent optimism coursing through South Africa's research community. Twenty years on, Michael Cherry finds that it is still struggling to get on its feet.
title: South African science: black, white and grey

author: Rex Dalton
description: Eske Willerslev combines Arctic escapades with meticulous lab work in his quest to pull ancient DNA from the ice. Rex Dalton talks to the adventurer about extracting the first ancient human genome.
title: Palaeogenetics: Icy resolve

author: Ananyo Bhattacharya
description: Researchers in France have switched on the world's most powerful nuclear magnetic resonance instrument. Ananyo Bhattacharya asks whether it will attract new life to NMR spectroscopy.
title: Chemistry: Breaking the billion-hertz barrier

author: Katharine Gammon
description: The Internet is struggling to keep up with the ever-increasing demands placed on it. Katharine Gammon looks at ways to fix it.
title: Networking: Four ways to reinvent the Internet

author: Corie Lok
description: Scientists are struggling to make sense of the expanding scientific literature. Corie Lok asks whether computational tools can do the hard work for them.
title: Literature mining: Speed reading

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: The surprising discovery of methane in Mars's atmosphere could be a sign of life there. Researchers are now working out how to find its source, reports Katharine Sanderson.
title: Planetary science: A whiff of mystery on Mars

author: Daniel Cressey
description: Alan Ashworth took a cancer drug from Petri dish to patients in near record speed. Daniel Cressey meets a biologist who is evangelical about translational research.
title: Translational research: Talking up translation

author: Roberta Kwok
description: Can engineering approaches tame the complexity of living systems? Roberta Kwok explores five challenges for the field and how they might be resolved.
title: Five hard truths for synthetic biology

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Like any other field, research on climate change has some fundamental gaps, although not the ones typically claimed by sceptics. Quirin Schiermeier takes a hard look at some of the biggest problem areas.
title: The real holes in climate science

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: An increase in premature births means that more babies are at risk of neurological damage. Erika Check Hayden talks with researchers who are developing ways to help these children.
title: Neuroscience: The most vulnerable brains

author: Brendan Maher
description: Richard Besser led the United States' top public-health agency as swine flu broke out on its doorstep. And his communication shaped the early days of a pandemic, finds Brendan Maher.
title: Swine flu: Crisis communicator

author: Mark Schrope
description: An annual excursion to an exclusive Caribbean island has yielded an impressive body of ecological fieldwork. Just don't call it a holiday, says Mark Schrope.
title: Ecology: Wish you were here

author: David Lindley
description: Renewable energy is not a viable option unless energy can be stored on a large scale. David Lindley looks at five ways to do that.
title: Smart grids: The energy storage problem

author: Colin Macilwain
description: A network of social scientists in the United Kingdom is seeking better ways to study the work of biologists. But, asks Colin Macilwain, can it earn its subjects' trust?
title: Genetics: Watching science at work

author: Elie Dolgin
description: Dedicated scientists are working hard to close the gaps, fix the errors and finally complete the human genome sequence. Elie Dolgin looks at how close they are.
title: Human genomics: The genome finishers

author: Anjali Nayar
description: How do you persuade philanthropists to pay $1 million for every pathogenic human virus you discover? Anjali Nayar talks to 'virus hunter' Nathan Wolfe in Cameroon to find out.
title: Emerging disease: Looking for trouble

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: The United Nations Climate Change Conference is mainly a political affair but it has drawn hundreds of scientists to the Danish capital. Jeff Tollefson finds out what they hope to gain.
title: Copenhagen: the scientists' view

author: Nicola Nosengo
description: An underwater effort to detect subatomic particles has ended up detecting sperm whales instead. Nicola Nosengo reports on a partnership between marine biologists and particle physicists.
title: Underwater acoustics: The neutrino and the whale

author: Meredith Wadman
description: The new head of the US Food and Drug Administration has inherited an agency battered by crises. Meredith Wadman asks whether Peggy Hamburg can concoct a cure.
title: The FDA: A tough tonic

author: Lucas Laursen
description: An intuitive approach to computer modelling could reveal paths to discovery, finds Lucas Laursen.
title: Computational biology: Biological logic

author: Emma Marris
description: Gretchen Daily knows the value of ecosystems — but can ascribing financial worth to them help to maintain biodiversity? Emma Marris meets an ecosystem-services evangelist.
title: Biodiversity: Putting a price on nature

author: Gene Russo
description: While species losses mount worldwide, conservationists in Brazil have made great strides towards saving the golden lion tamarin and its forest habitat from destruction. Gene Russo reports.
title: Biodiversity: Biodiversity's bright spot

author: Nick Lane
description: Genetic sequences in a cell's mitochondria can be used to accurately determine species. Could this be because they are responsible for creating what they identify? Nick Lane investigates.
title: Biodiversity: On the origin of bar codes

author: Emma Marris
description: Unsatisfied with merely halting environmental destruction, some conservationists are trying to reconstruct ecosystems of the past. Emma Marris travels back in time with the rewilders.
title: Conservation biology: Reflecting the past

author: Anjali Nayar
description: Projects in Madagascar could provide a model for stemming deforestation. But first these efforts must deal with the poverty and political upheaval that threaten forests, reports Anjali Nayar.
title: Carbon trading: How to save a forest

author: Erik Vance
description: Sean Mackey inflicts pain on people in the hope of learning how to relieve it. Erik Vance gets on the receiving end.
title: Neuroscience: Shooting pain

author: Michael Bond
description: Can the general public learn to evaluate risks accurately, or do authorities need to steer it towards correct decisions? Michael Bond talks to the two opposing camps.
title: Decision-making: Risk school

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: If the next climate treaty tackles deforestation, tropical nations will need to monitor the biomass of their forests. One ecologist has worked out a way to do that from the sky, finds Jeff Tollefson.
title: Climate: Counting carbon in the Amazon

author: Anjali Nayar
description: Deep in the Himalayas, the disappearance of glaciers is threatening the kingdom of Bhutan. Anjali Nayar trekked through the mountains to see how the country is adapting to a warming world.
title: Climate: When the ice melts

author: Glennda Chui
description: Geological faults are not behaving as scientists once expected. Glennda Chui reports on efforts to forge a new understanding of quake behaviour.
title: Seismology: Shaking up earthquake theory

author: Alison Abbott
description: Neurosurgeons have unparalleled access to the human brain. Now they are teaming up with basic researchers to work out what makes it unique, finds Alison Abbott.
title: Neuroscience: Opening up brain surgery

author: Jonah Lehrer
description: Researchers have engineered more than 30 strains of 'smart mice', revealing possible ways to boost human brains. But, as Jonah Lehrer finds, cognitive enhancement may come at a cost.
title: Neuroscience: Small, furry … and smart

author: Natasha Gilbert
description: Phosphate-based fertilizers have helped spur agricultural gains in the past century, but the world may soon run out of them. Natasha Gilbert investigates the potential phosphate crisis.
title: Environment: The disappearing nutrient

author: Kelly Rae Chi
description: Genome-wide association studies have identified hundreds of genetic clues to disease. Kelly Rae Chi looks at three to see just how on-target the approach seems to be.
title: Human genetics: Hit or miss?

author: Joerg Heber
description: Small oscillations of surface electrons that manipulate light on the nanoscale could be the route to applications as disparate as faster computer chips and cures for cancer. Joerg Heber reports.
title: Plasmonics: Surfing the wave

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: The collapse of communism opened up the world to scientists from eastern Europe. Quirin Schiermeier talks to researchers about what changed.
title: Eastern Europe: Scaling the wall

author: Jane Qiu
description: When American and Chinese scientists agreed to measure pollution and dust over China, nobody foresaw how difficult it would be. Jane Qiu reports.
title: Atmospheric science: Cloudy, with a chance of science

author: Eric Hand
description: Canada's Perimeter Institute of Theoretical Physics was intended to become a world leader in the field. Eric Hand finds out if it has lived up to its ambitions.
title: Physics: The edge of physics

author: Daniel Cressey
description: How do researchers and policy-makers decide on the value of health? Daniel Cressey looks at Britain's National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence.
title: Health economics: Life in the balance

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Paul Thacker, a reporter-turned-Congressional-investigator, has disrupted the careers of several top researchers with lucrative industry ties. Meredith Wadman tracks his effect on US science.
title: Money in biomedicine: The senator's sleuth

author: Henry Nicholls
description: Hagfish and lampreys are the only surviving fish without jaws. And they could solve an evolutionary mystery, finds Henry Nicholls.
title: Evolution: Mouth to mouth

author: Bryn Nelson
description: Most researchers agree that open access to data is the scientific ideal, so what is stopping it happening? Bryn Nelson investigates why many researchers choose not to share.
title: Data sharing: Empty archives

author: Jane Qiu
description: Lightning and fires on the Arctic tundra seem to be on the rise. Jane Qiu meets the researchers learning from the scorched earth in Alaska.
title: Arctic ecology: Tundra's burning

author: Emily Waltz
description: Papers suggesting that biotech crops might harm the environment attract a hail of abuse from other scientists. Emily Waltz asks if the critics fight fair.
title: GM crops: Battlefield

author: Nicola Nosengo
description: He looks like a child and plays like a child. But can the iCub robot reveal how a child learns and thinks? Nicola Nosengo reports.
title: Robotics: The bot that plays ball

author: Brendan Maher
description: Some diseases defy diagnosis. Brendan Maher meets two people who hope that the US National Institutes of Health can help.
title: Medicine: Last chance clinic

author: Alison Abbott
description: Patients checking in to the German Mouse Clinic will undergo the most sophisticated medical testing in the world. But, finds Alison Abbott, the waiting list is becoming a problem.
title: Mouse genetics: The check-up

author: Virginia Gewin
description: Ecologists have struggled to reconcile what they see in the lab and in the wild. But both views are needed to understand the effects of extinction, finds Virginia Gewin.
title: Biodiversity: Rack and field

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: When nations made plans to save the ozone layer, they didn't factor in global warming. Quirin Schiermeier reports on how two environmental problems complicate each other.
title: Atmospheric science: Fixing the sky

author: Mark Buchanan
description: Could agent-based computer models prevent another financial crisis? Mark Buchanan reports.
title: Economics: Meltdown modelling

author: Erik Vance
description: A vast supply of energy is racing around the planet far above the surface. Erik Vance meets the engineers trying to bring the power of high-altitude wind down to earth.
title: Wind power: High hopes

author: Jeanne Erdmann
description: Multiphoton microscopy is allowing immunologists to watch infections as they happen. Jeanne Erdmann pulls up a seat.
title: Immunology: Lights, camera, infection

author: Ehsan Masood
description: Maurice Strong has shaped how nations respond to planetary crises. Ehsan Masood meets the man whose successes — and failures — laid the groundwork for the current climate talks.
title: Environment: The globe's green avenger

author: Emma Marris
description: A small group of ecologists is looking beyond the pristine to study the scrubby, feral and untended. Emma Marris learns to appreciate 'novel ecosystems'.
title: Ecology: Ragamuffin Earth

author: Anjali Nayar
description: Africa's Lake Kivu contains vast quantities of gas, which makes it both dangerous and valuable. Anjali Nayar asks whether it is possible to tap the gas without causing a disaster.
title: Earth science: A lakeful of trouble

author: Kendall Powell
description: Cellular life is all slopes, arcs and circles — but there is much debate about how these curves are built. Kendall Powell reports.
title: Cell biology: Ahead of the curve

author: David Cyranoski
description: With its electron microscope, genetic sequencing machines and observatory, the Yokohama Science Frontier High School is equipped like no other. Will future scientists be inspired there, asks David Cyranoski.
title: Science education: Reading, writing and nanofabrication

author: Helen Pearson
description: When the cystic fibrosis gene was found in 1989, therapy seemed around the corner. Two decades on, biologists still have a long way to go, finds Helen Pearson.
title: Human genetics: One gene, twenty years

author: Ed Gerstner
description: Slotting a fusion reactor into the heart of a nuclear fission plant could accelerate the development of waste-free nuclear energy. So why are all the designs still on paper, asks Ed Gerstner.
title: Nuclear energy: The hybrid returns

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: With their focus on greenhouse gases, atmospheric scientists have largely overlooked lowly soot particles. But black carbon is now a hot topic among researchers and politicians. Jeff Tollefson investigates.
title: Atmospheric science: Climate's smoky spectre

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Blogs and Twitter are opening up meetings to those not actually there. Does that mean too much access to science in the raw, asks Geoff Brumfiel.
title: Science journalism: Breaking the convention?

author: Heidi Ledford
description: The iPlant programme was designed to give plant scientists a new information infrastructure. But first they had to decide what they wanted, finds Heidi Ledford.
title: Cyberinfrastructure: Feed me data

author: Emma Marris
description: While conservation biologists debate whether to move organisms threatened by the warming climate, one forester in British Columbia is already doing it. Emma Marris reports.
title: Forestry: Planting the forest of the future

author: Nicola Jones
description: Metrologists are on a path to redefine the unit of temperature. The freezing point of water will never be the same again, finds Nicola Jones.
title: Metrology: The new and improved kelvin

author: Amanda Leigh Mascarelli
description: The boundaries of biology reach farther below Earth's surface than scientists had thought possible. Amanda Leigh Mascarelli delves into how microbes survive deep underground.
title: Geomicrobiology: Low life

author: Jim Schnabel
description: Assessing the effects of television on young children is far from easy. But, as researchers tell Jim Schnabel, that is no reason not to try.
title: Media research: The black box

author: Erik Vance
description: Chemist Allen Goldstein has spent his career tracking elusive compounds emitted by trees. Erik Vance joined him for a tour of the woods.
title: Atmospheric chemistry: The man who smells forests

description: What do protein crystallographers dream of? The eukaryotic ribosome, the spliceosome, the nuclear-pore complex, the HIV trimer and almost any transmembrane protein, finds Ananyo Bhattacharya.
title: Protein structures: Structures of desire

description: It's simple to mop carbon dioxide out of the air, but it could cost a lot of money. In the second of three features on the carbon challenge, Nicola Jones talks with the scientists pursuing this strategy.
title: Climate crunch: Sucking it up

description: Geoengineering schemes, such as brightening clouds, are being talked about ever more widely. In the third of three features, Oliver Morton looks at how likely they are to work.

author: Richard Monastersky

title: Climate crunch: A burden beyond bearing

author: Monya Baker
description: The field of induced pluripotent stem cells has gone from standing start to headlong rush in less than three years. Monya Baker charts the course so far, and the obstacles ahead.
title: Stem cells: Fast and furious

author: Roberta Kwok
description: Far from being just an accessory, mobile phones are starting to be used to collect data in an increasing number of disciplines. Roberta Kwok looks into their potential.
title: Personal technology: Phoning in data

author: Eric Hand
description: As the launch of the Planck spacecraft approaches, Eric Hand investigates what the mission could mean for the predominant theory of the moments after the Big Bang.
title: Cosmology: The test of inflation

author: David Cyranoski
description: Could genes explain the remarkable rate of identical twins born in some remote villages around the world? David Cyranoski investigates a long-standing biological curiosity.
title: Developmental biology: Two by two

author: Alison Abbott
description: While researchers in Greece starve for government support, biomedicine is thriving at a lavish new centre in Athens, finds Alison Abbott.
title: Greek research: Feast and famine

author: Brendan Maher
description: From Antarctic icefish to Galapagos finches, there are some interesting characters at the fringes of developmental biology. Brendan Maher explores a world of alternative model organisms.
title: Evolution: Biology's next top model?

author: Declan Butler
description: Undergraduate textbooks are going digital. Declan Butler asks how this will shake up student reading habits and the multi-billion-dollar print textbook market.
title: Technology: The textbook of the future

author: Alison Abbott
description: From a home lab to the Italian Senate, by way of nerve growth factor — Rita Levi-Montalcini is a scientist like no other. Alison Abbott meets the first Nobel prizewinner set to reach her hundredth birthday.
title: Neuroscience: One hundred years of Rita

author: Daniel Cressey
description: The only way to meet the increasing demand for fish is through aquaculture. Daniel Cressey explores the challenges for fish farmers and what it means for dinner plates in 2030.
title: Aquaculture: Future fish

author: Roberta Kwok
description: When an asteroid was spotted heading towards our planet last October, researchers rushed to document a cosmic impact from start to finish for the first time. Roberta Kwok tells the tale.
title: Astronomy: The rock that fell to Earth

author: Katharine Gammon
description: The switch to electronic medical records opens up a potential wealth of data for researchers, if major obstacles can be overcome, reports Katharine Gammon.
title: Clinical epidemiology: Archived answers

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Science journalism is in decline; science blogging is growing fast. But can the one replace the other, asks Geoff Brumfiel.
title: Science journalism: Supplanting the old media?

author: Melissa Lee Phillips
description: Could out-of-sync body clocks be contributing to human disease? Melissa Lee Phillips reports.
title: Circadian rhythms: Of owls, larks and alarm clocks

author: David Lindley
description: Waste heat from industrial plants and electricity-generating stations represents a huge amount of lost energy. David Lindley finds out what engineers and regulators need to do to get it back.
title: The energy should always work twice

author: Jim Schnabel
description: Alcoholics Anonymous and its spin-off programmes have been helping people with addictions for decades. Jim Schnabel talks to the neuroscientists who are looking deeper into the approach.
title: Neuroscience: Rethinking rehab

author: Helen Pearson
description: Running one of the biggest academic labs in America gives Robert Langer almost 100 people to help and advise; his BlackBerry gives him the rest of the world. Helen Pearson joins the throng.
title: Profile: Being Bob Langer

author: Richard Monastersky
description: As change in the Arctic accelerates, scientists and indigenous peoples have pressing reasons to work together, reports Richard Monastersky.
title: International Polar Year: The social pole?

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: As scientists celebrate the end of the International Polar Year, they see causes for concern on the frozen horizon, reports Quirin Schiermeier.
title: International Polar Year: In from the Cold

author: Emma Marris
description: What does it mean to save a species? For some, preserving the American bison means keeping its genome pure, finds Emma Marris.
title: Conservation: The genome of the American West

author: Erika  Check Hayden
description: Geneticists looked to the human genome to understand human evolution. But it's hard to interpret without considering the inheritance of culture, finds Erika Check Hayden.
title: Darwin 200: The other strand

author: Dan Jones
description: People's mindsets are neither fixed by evolution nor infinitely malleable by culture. Dan Jones looks for the similarities that underlie the diversity of human nature.
title: Darwin 200: Human nature: the remix

author: Mark Buchanan
description: Are people's interactions driven by a primitive, non-linguistic type of communication? Mark Buchanan looks at how modern technology can reveal the basis of our powers of persuasion.
title: Behavioural Science: Secret signals

author: Jonah Lehrer
description: By turning neurons technicolour, Jeff Lichtman exposed the brain's wiring. Jonah Lehrer meets the 'unapologetic cell biologist' with ambitions to map every connection in the human brain.
title: Neuroscience: Making connections

author: Lea Winerman
description: Messages appear on Internet-based social networks within minutes of disasters occurring. Lea Winerman investigates how to harness this trend to create official community-response grids.
title: Social networking: Crisis communication

author: David Cyranoski
description: After spurning wind power, China has swung around and embraced this clean energy. But the nation's love affair with wind may be spinning out of control, finds David Cyranoski.
title: Renewable energy: Beijing's windy bet

author: Declan Butler
description: In the first of three features on the legacy of the Bush administration, Declan Butler looks at the United States' failure to deal with the risks of nuclear proliferation.
title: Bush's legacy: The wasted years

author: Mark Schrope
description: A look at George W. Bush's legacy in science.
title: Bush's legacy: 43 by the numbers

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: Was setting up PEPFAR — a massive HIV treatment programme — the best thing that President Bush ever did? Erika Check Hayden investigates.
title: Bush's legacy: An unlikely champion

author: Mark Schrope
description: The best way to study life beneath the waves is to live there. Mark Schrope describes his experiences in the world's longest-running undersea laboratory.
title: Ocean research: The lab at the bottom of the sea

author: Paroma Basu
description: If growing forests in India can generate lucrative carbon credits, then why isn't everyone planting trees? Paroma Basu reports.
title: Forestry: A green investment

author: Jeff Kanipe
description: The next 40 years will see telescopes that far outstrip any ever seen before. Jeff Kanipe profiles four of them; illustrations by Lynette Cook.
title: Year of astronomy: New eyes, new skies

author: Ashley Yeager
description: Medals, cash and fame rained down on the heads of prominent scientists in 2008. Ashley Yeager rounds up some of them.
title: News 2008: Prizewinners of the year

author: Claire Ainsworth
description: Squash them, pinch them, twist them, pull them — cells react to physical forces, finds Claire Ainsworth.
title: Cell biology: Stretching the imagination

author: Eric Hand
description: Eric Hand reports on the short life and hard times of the little Mars lander that sort-of-could.
title: Mars exploration: Phoenix: a race against time

author: Emma Marris
description: The current crisis in worldwide food prices reinforces the need for more productive agriculture. Emma Marris meets five ambitious scientists determined to stop the world from going hungry.
title: Agronomy: Five crop researchers who could change the world

author: Rex Dalton
description: Argentina's government has pledged to reverse a decades-long scientific brain drain. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Argentina: The come back

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: A new generation of lithium-ion batteries, coupled with rising oil prices and the need to address climate change, has sparked a global race to electrify transportation. Jeff Tollefson investigates.
title: Car industry: Charging up the future

author: Simon Ings
description: A celebration of one of evolution's crowning glories.
title: Darwin 200: An eye for the eye

author: Henry Nicholls
description: Evolution assumes that extinction is forever. Maybe not. Henry Nicholls asks what it would take to bring the woolly mammoth back from the dead.
title: Darwin 200: Let's make a mammoth

author: Tanguy Chouard
description: You might think that once evolution has found one way to get something done, it will stick with it. But similar physical forms can hide radically different wiring, finds Tanguy Chouard.
title: Darwin 200: Beneath the surface

author: Alison Abbott
description: Neuroscientists are pretty sure they know what causes Alzheimer's disease, but their theory has not yet given rise to effective drugs. Alison Abbott asks what's wrong.
title: Neuroscience: The plaque plan

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: Could the next generation of genetic sequencing machines be built from a collection of minuscule holes? Katharine Sanderson reports.
title: Personal genomes: Standard and pores

author: Bryn Nelson
description: Eric Schadt revels in making people uncomfortable with his science. Bryn Nelson reports how the bioinformatics rabble-rouser hopes to charge ahead in the face of his company's disintegration.
title: Personal genomes: A disruptive personality, disrupted

author: Brendan Maher
description: When scientists opened up the human genome, they expected to find the genetic components of common traits and diseases. But they were nowhere to be seen. Brendan Maher shines a light on six places where the missing loot could be stashed away.
title: Personal genomes: The case of the missing heritability

author: David Lindley
description: Electronic voting machines were supposed to vanquish unreliable counts. They did not -- but David Lindley finds that other technologies present their own problems.
title: US election: Ghosts in the machine

author: Rex Dalton
description: Native Americans want to claim fossil resources found on their lands. Rex Dalton looks at how tribes and palaeontologists are working together to avoid bitter ownership disputes.
title: Palaeontology: School of rock

author: Eric Hand
description: The International Space Station's one chance of scientific greatness rests on a high-profile refugee from the world of the particle accelerator - but is it too long a shot to be worth taking? Eric Hand reports.
title: Particle physics: Sam Ting's last fling

author: Jane Qiu
description: In an effort to avoid a food crisis as the population grows, China is putting its weight behind genetically modified strains of the country's staple food crop. Jane Qiu explores the reasons for the unprecedented push.
title: Agriculture: Is China ready for GM rice?

author: Amber Dance
description: More creatures live in soil than any other environment on Earth. But what are they all doing there? Amber Dance reports on the world's widest biodiversity.
title: Soil ecology: What lies beneath

author: Erik Vance
description: Jacek Koziel is a master of odours. On a pig farm in Iowa, he shows Erik Vance some of the peaks and troughs of life as a human detector.
title: Profile: What is that smell?

author: John Whitfield
description: What makes a successful team? John Whitfield looks at research that uses massive online databases and network analysis to come up with some rules of thumb for productive collaborations.
title: Collaboration: Group theory

author: Sharon Weinberger
description: What began several years ago as an attempt to recruit social scientists to help the military has sparked a broader debate about militarizing academia. Sharon Weinberger reports.
title: Military research: The Pentagon's culture wars

author: Monya Baker
description: Cell therapies are as much about the patients as they are about the cells. Monya Baker meets two stem-cell scientists who have decided to put people first.
title: Cell therapy: Being patient

author: Alexandra Witze
description: The leading US presidential candidates are not trying to woo voters with science issues. But the senator who wins will help shape the world's most influential research agenda. Alexandra Witze looks at how John McCain and Barack Obama have developed their thoughts on science and technology, and where each of them might take the country if elected.
title: US election: The home stretch

author: Kendall Powell
description: What is it like to be labelled a genius? Kendall Powell follows the paths of four MacArthur Fellows — and finds they lead to rutting elephant bulls, climate-change champions, hybrid sunflowers and robotic hands.
title: Science prizes: Best in class

author: Emma Marris
description: Białowieża is one of the best-preserved woodlands in Europe. But is it a good reference point for what Europe looked like 5,000 years ago? Emma Marris goes deep into the forest to find out.
title: Ecology: The heart of the wood

author: John Whitfield
description: This summer a group of high-profile researchers met in Altenberg, Austria, to try and plot the future course of evolutionary theory. John Whitfield was there.
title: Biological theory: Postmodern evolution?

author: Rex Dalton
description: Palaeontologists in Argentina are exploring a trove of fossils that is rewriting evolutionary history. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Palaeontology: The new mother lode

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: The Large Hadron Collider is the latest attempt to move fundamental physics past the frustratingly successful 'standard model'. But it is not the only way to do it. Geoff Brumfiel surveys the contenders attempting to capture the prize before the collider gets up to speed.
title: Particle physics: The race to break the standard model

author: Helen Pearson
description: Proteins with 'zinc fingers' designed to bind almost any DNA sequence will soon be available to any lab that wants them — from two very different sources. Helen Pearson reports on a revolution in designer biology.
title: Protein engineering: The fate of fingers

author: Cory Doctorow
description: What does it take to store bytes by the tens of thousands of trillions? Cory Doctorow meets the people and machines for which it's all in a day's work.
title: Big data: Welcome to the petacentre

author: Mitch Waldrop
description: Pioneering biologists are trying to use wiki-type web pages to manage and interpret data, reports Mitch Waldrop. But will the wider research community go along with the experiment?
title: Big data: Wikiomics

author: Patrick Goymer
description: Cancer cells vary; they compete; the fittest survive. Patrick Goymer reports on how evolutionary biology can be applied to cancer — and what good it might do.
title: Natural selection: The evolution of cancer

author: Anna Petherick
description: If more than 90% of the genome is 'junk' then why do cells make so much RNA from it? Anna Petherick goes in search of some answers.
title: Genetics: The production line

author: Jerry Guo
description: Recent eruptions and field expeditions may herald a return to glory for the Son of Krakatau. Jerry Guo explores what the 78-year-old island has to offer.
title: Volcanology: Fire and life

author: Tony Scully
description: When jumbo Humboldt squid disappeared from Chilean waters, it led to the demise of a world-class electrophysiology laboratory. Now the creatures are back, finds Tony Scully, and so are the scientists.
title: Neuroscience: The great squid hunt

author: Jim Schnabel
description: Questions raised about the use of 'ALS mice' are prompting a broad reappraisal of the way that drugs are tested in animal models of neurodegenerative disease. Jim Schnabel reports.
title: Neuroscience: Standard model

author: Corie Lok
description: Harvard is embarking on an experiment to foster collaboration and interdisciplinary research. Corie Lok looks at whether it can change its culture and reinvent communities along the way.
title: Interdisciplinary science: Harvard under review

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: Researchers trying to develop an HIV vaccine have endured two decades of setbacks. Erika Check Hayden meets a veteran still engaged in the fight — and a rookie willing to join in anyway.
title: HIV: The next shot

author: Emma Marris
description: Electricity grids must cope with rising demand and complexity in a changing world. Emma Marris explores the intricacies involved in controlling the power supply.
title: Energy: Upgrading the grid

author: Laura Spinney
description: Armed with a map depicting a 10,000-year-old landscape submerged beneath the North Sea and fresh evidence from nearby sites, archaeologists are realizing that early humans were more territorial than was previously thought. Laura Spinney reports.
title: Archaeology: The lost world

author: Alison Abbott
description: Does the difficulty in finding the genes responsible for mental illness reflect the complexity of the genetics or the poor definitions of psychiatric disorders? Alison Abbott reports.
title: Psychiatric genetics: The brains of the family

author: Bruce Lieberman
description: A difference in one molecule led physician Ajit Varki to question what sets humans apart from other apes. Bruce Lieberman meets a man who sees a big picture in the finer points.
title: Human evolution: Details of being human

author: Rex Dalton
description: Entomologists are briefing the military on how to protect troops from the scourge of the desert: sandflies. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Entomology: Battlefield insectica

author: David Cyranoski
description: Can the Chinese government meet its ambitious targets on space, the environment, research, energy and health? David Cyranoski takes a look at China today and what it hopes to be tomorrow.
title: China: Visions of China

author: Eric Hand
description: Not all NASA launches need rockets and countdowns. Eric Hand sees the alternative in Fort Sumner, New Mexico.
title: Space science: From the desert to the edge of space

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: China burns more coal than any other country; how it does so in the future will determine our planet's climate. Jeff Tollefson reports from Beijing.
title: China: Stoking the fire

author: Jane Qiu
description: Climate change is coming fast and furious to the Tibetan plateau. Jane Qiu reports on the changes atop the roof of the world.
title: China: The third pole

author: Duncan Steel
description: The most dramatic cosmic impact in recent history has gathered up almost as many weird explanations as it knocked down trees, writes Duncan Steel.
title: Planetary science: Tunguska at 100

author: Eric Hand
description: A giant crater on the lunar farside holds the key to a catastrophic bombardment that reshaped the Moon, Earth and other planets. Eric Hand reports.
title: Planetary science: The hole at the bottom of the Moon

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: As the first grants from the European Research Council begin to come through, Geoff Brumfiel investigates whether the new system is meeting its goals.
title: Funding: The research revolution

author: Jane Qiu
description: Is it really possible to stop rain, invoke lightning from the heavens or otherwise manipulate the weather? Jane Qiu and Daniel Cressey report on the once-scorned notion of weather modification.
title: Meteorology: Taming the sky

author: Declan Butler
description: A chasm has opened up between biomedical researchers and the patients who need their discoveries. Declan Butler asks how the ground shifted and whether the US National Institutes of Health can bridge the gap.
title: Translational research: Crossing the valley of death

author: Heidi Ledford
description: Results can be thrust from bench to bedside, but there is also much to be learned by pushing the other way. Heidi Ledford tells tales of clinical trials that have prompted a change in tack.
title: Translational Research: The full cycle

author: Helen Pearson
description: The Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research is focused on translating research into cures. Helen Pearson investigates whether its sometimes unusual methods are producing results.
title: Translational research: A case history

author: Nick Lane
description: Programmed cell death is usually seen as the unique prerogative of plants and animals. So how is it that photosynthetic plankton have been killing themselves by uncannily similar methods for billions of years? Nick Lane investigates.
title: Marine microbiology: Origins of Death

author: Laura Spinney
description: A major, but flawed, study of identity parades, or line-ups, has set science and the police at odds. Laura Spinney investigates.
title: Eyewitness identification: Line-ups on trial

author: Emma Marris
description: Some researchers think that the evolution of languages can be understood by treating them like genomes - but many linguists don't want to hear about it. Emma Marris reports.
title: Language: The language barrier

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: A high-profile scientist, a graduate student and two major retractions. Erika Check Hayden reports on a case that has rocked the chemistry community.
title: Chemistry: Designer debacle

author: Rachel Courtland
description: A new way to analyse seismic vibrations is bringing order out of noise to help predict volcanic eruptions or create detailed images of Earth's interior. Rachel Courtland reports.
title: Earth science: Harnessing the hum

author: Helen Pearson
description: The inner life of a cell is noisy. Helen Pearson discovers how the resulting randomness makes life more challenging - and richer.
title: Cell biology: The cellular hullabaloo

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: Can a state do what a country cannot, and transform the way stem-cell research is funded? Erika Check Hayden reports on the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine.
title: Stem cells: The 3-billion-dollar question

author: Philip Ball
description: How does our classical world emerge from the counterintuitive principles of quantum theory? Can we even be sure that the world doesn't 'go quantum' when no one is watching? Philip Ball talks to the theorists and experimentalists trying to find out.
title: Physics: Quantum all the way

author: Sharon Weinberger
description: Battling rumours of death beams and mind control, an ionosphere research facility in Alaska finally brings science to the fore. Sharon Weinberger reports.
title: Atmospheric physics: Heating up the heavens

author: Bijal Trivedi
description: Lyle Palmer has plans for a 'ludicrously ambitious' gene - disease research project. Bijal Trivedi reports on the trials at Joondalup.
title: Biomedical science: Betting the bank

author: Rex Dalton
description: Old human remains found on the Pacific islands of Palau are caught in the crossfire between entertainment and science. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Archaeology: Bones, isles and videotape

author: Alexandra Witze
description: Is the Arctic's biggest ice sheet in irreversible meltdown? And would we know if it were? Alexandra Witze reports.
title: Climate change: Losing Greenland

author: Liesbeth Venema
description: Some experts think that a quantum computation could be plaited like a skein of string. And now they may have found the sorts of string they need, finds Liesbeth Venema.
title: Quantum computation: The dreamweaver's abacus

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: Some creatures have what it takes to survive long dry spells. How they do this may be revealed in their genes, reports Erika Check Hayden.
title: Evolution: Scandal! Sex-starved and still surviving

author: Heidi Ledford
description: Collaborations spawn fresh ideas and boost productivity - most of the time. Heidi Ledford examines what happens when a working relationship breaks down, and asks how to avoid it.
title: Collaborations: With all good intentions

author: Erik Vance
description: Sometimes it is necessary to immerse yourself in a subject. Erik Vance meets a woman whose research takes her deep — waist-deep — into cetacean anatomy.
title: Anatomy: Truly gross anatomy

author: Alison Abbott
description: Portugal's spending on research is near the lowest in western Europe. Can a single-minded lady with half a billion euros change things, asks Alison Abbott.
title: Portugal: Navigating new waters

author: Declan Butler
description: Low- and zero-energy buildings could have a huge impact on energy use and carbon emissions. We have the technologies, but if they are to mitigate climate change, green-building design must hit the mass market, says Declan Butler.
title: Architecture: Architects of a low-energy future

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: Chemists have long wanted to recreate photosynthesis in the lab — and to improve on its efficiency at converting sunlight into fuel. Katharine Sanderson reports on their latest efforts.
title: Chemistry: The photon trap

author: Michael Hopkin
description: The 'Doomsday vault' buried in the Arctic ice will provide a backup for the world's seeds. But more needs to be done to safeguard food diversity, says Michael Hopkin.
title: Biodiversity: Frozen futures

author: David Cyranoski
description: Induced pluripotent stem cells look just like embryonic stem cells, but are easier to create and free of the heavy ethics baggage. David Cyranoski separates fact from fiction in a burgeoning field.
title: Stem cells: 5 things to know before jumping on the iPS bandwagon

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: In parts of the world already facing unreliable food supplies, an uncertain climate adds to the future stress for soils, plants and people. Quirin Schiermeier reports on water strategies for a drier world.
title: Water: A long dry summer

author: Rex Dalton
description: A surprisingly large number of university-inspired patents may be going to industry instead. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Business: Stepping out

author: Ewen Callaway
description: Huanglongbing, a disease that could devastate the US citrus industry, pits national security against plant pathologists looking to battle natural outbreaks, Ewen Callaway reports.
title: Bioterror: The green menace

author: Eric Hand
description: Three teams are racing each other to build the next generation of telescopes that would dramatically dwarf the largest on Earth today. Eric Hand checks out the competition.
title: Astronomy: Eyes as big as the sky

author: Mark Schrope
description: Algal blooms can make life miserable for coastal dwellers and wreak havoc on marine ecosystems. Mark Schrope reports on Florida's efforts to predict these red tides.
title: Oceanography: Red tide rising

author: Rex Dalton
description: New York University is trying to establish a world-class archaeological institute — with funds from a philanthropist who has been linked to looted artefacts. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Archaeology: Facing up to the past

author: Trudy E. Bell
description: The cosmos is thought to be awash with gravitational waves to which humanity is, as yet, deaf. Trudy E. Bell reports on LISA, an experiment on an unprecedented scale designed to put that right.
title: Gravitational astronomy: Hearing the heavens

author: Michael Hopkin
description: Zambia, with help from partners around the world, is stepping up its battle against malaria. Michael Hopkin reports from the rural front line.
title: Malaria: The big push

author: Brendan Maher
description: After decades of work, a pioneering malaria vaccine may soon reach the final phase of clinical trials. In the first of two features on efforts against malaria, Brendan Maher reports on a vaccine that is far from perfect - but which may provide new direction and save thousands of lives.
title: Malaria: The end of the beginning

author: Vicki Cleave
description: The dream of perpetual flight without fuel has inspired pilots to take to the skies in solar-powered planes. Vicki Cleave looks at a mission to fly a solar plane through the night - and around the world.
title: Solar power: A flight to remember

author: Jane Qiu
description: Chinese authors are publishing more and more papers, but are they receiving due credit and recognition for their work? Not if their names get confused along the way. Jane Qiu reports.
title: Scientific publishing: Identity crisis

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: George Church has made a name for himself as an 'information exhibitionist'. Erika Check Hayden explores how the technological sage is turning his gaze to the next horizon - you.
title: Profile: Meet Exhibit I

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Scientists and politicians in New Jersey thought that they had a chance to make their state a stem-cell player. Voters thought otherwise. As proponents prepare for a second attempt, Meredith Wadman investigates what went wrong in the Garden State.
title: Stem cells: Stuck in New Jersey

author: Dan Jones
description: What can evolution say about why humans kill - and about why we do so less than we used to? Dan Jones reports.
title: Human behaviour: Killer instincts

author: Monya Baker
description: Genomewide association studies are starting to turn up increasingly reliable disease markers. Monya Baker investigates where we are now and what comes next.
title: Genome studies: Genetics by numbers

author: Sharon Weinberger
description: Half a century after its creation, the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is considered a paragon of government innovation. But some question whether it is still relevant. Sharon Weinberger reports.
title: Defence research: Still in the lead?

author: Melinda Wenner
description: Viral and microbial interactions within living tissues are more complex than previously thought. Melinda Wenner explores whether a periodic table of the infectious could help sort out the mess.
title: Virology: The battle within

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Physicists often borrow techniques from other fields. But how far can this get you? Geoff Brumfiel asks if simple table-top experiments can provide new insights into the early Universe.
title: Experimental cosmology: Cosmos in a bottle

author: Brendan Borrell
description: A German physicist and a hedge-fund magnate are competing to push protein simulations into the realm of the millisecond. Brendan Borrell finds out what is at stake.
title: Chemistry: Power play

author: Mark Schrope
description: A winning combination of isolation, local involvement and a broad ecological remit are making the management of the seas around Colombia's San Andrés islands a model for other conservationists, reports Mark Schrope.
title: Conservation: Providential outcome

author: Ewen Callaway
description: Long dismissed as featureless, disorganized sacks, bacteria are now revealing a multitude of elegant internal structures. Ewen Callaway investigates a new field in cell biology.
title: Cell biology: Bacteria's new bones

author: Ehsan Masood
description: Are think-tanks staffed by scientists a luxury that only rich nations can afford? Ehsan Masood meets the founders of four institutes that set out to help poorer nations to think for themselves.
title: Capacity building: The road from Rio

author: Daniel Cressey
description: As countries race to file claims to areas of the sea floor before a United Nations deadline, geologists and geophysicists are getting caught up in the frenzy. Daniel Cressey reports.
title: Geology: The next land rush

author: Gabrielle Walker
description: In 2007, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change delivered its most thorough and authoritative assessment yet — and shared a Nobel prize for its efforts. Gabrielle Walker profiles its indefatigable leader.
title: Newsmaker of the year: Rajendra Pachauri

author: Rex Dalton
description: After decades of war, looting and destruction, Afghanistan's archaeologists are scrambling to restore their country's cultural heritage. Rex Dalton visited Kabul to see how they are faring.
title: Archaeology: Pieces of the puzzle

author: Emma Marris
description: Accustomed to adapting to nature's whims, gardeners are more prepared than most to take on the challenge of climate change. Emma Marris asks them what to grow in a greenhouse world.
title: Gardening: A garden for all climates

author: Alison Abbott
description: Are their brains not wired to feel what others feel, or do they just not care? Alison Abbott joins researchers looking into normal neurobiology through the scope of psychopathy.
title: Abnormal neuroscience: Scanning psychopaths

author: Alexandra Witze
description: The capacity of the United States to monitor Earth's vital signs is being stymied by tight budgets and poor coordination. Alexandra Witze reports.
title: Earth Monitoring: Not enough eyes on the prize

author: Declan Butler
description: Technology will soon allow the world to be mapped in near-real time and at high resolution. Declan Butler investigates the potential for operational monitoring of the planet.
title: Earth Monitoring: The planetary panopticon

author: Eric Hand
description: Hanging bright in the morning sky, Venus's allure is obvious; but its blasted surface looks too hot to handle. Eric Hand investigates the difficulties of returning to the closest planet - and new plans to reap the rewards of doing so.
title: Space and astronomy: The girl next door

author: Erika Check Hayden
description: Are ageing and disease two sides of the same coin? Erika Check Hayden reports from an institute that is betting that they are.
title: Age research: A new angle on 'old'

author: David Cyranoski
description: With keen immunological insight and a knockout mouse 'factory', Shizuo Akira leads by quiet example. David Cyranoski visits the world's most-cited scientist as he prepares to run one of Japan's premier research centres.
title: Profile: Innate ability

author: Mark Schrope
description: Far below the surface of the ocean, beyond the reach of the Sun's rays, organisms still have eyes. Mark Schrope investigates seeing without sunlight.
title: Marine biology: Lights in the deep

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: The next US president could lead the country into meaningful action on controlling greenhousegas emissions, but only if he, or she, can seize the moment. Jeff Tollefson reports.
title: Climate politics: Beyond Bush

author: Stephen Pincock
description: Climate is shaping up as an issue in the 24 November Australian elections, as Stephen Pincock reports.
title: Climate politics: Showdown in a sunburnt country

author: Ewen Callaway
description: Ocean wave energy is trying to break into the renewable-energy market, but many challenges remain. Ewen Callaway reports.
title: Energy: To catch a wave

author: Emma Marris
description: Not all species can be saved from extinction. Emma Marris talks to conservation biologists about prioritization and triage.
title: Conservation priorities: What to let go

author: David Cyranoski
description: The Japanese make few charitable donations. David Cyranoski meets a patient advocate and scientist working to change a cultural reticence about giving.
title: Philanthropy: A country without alms

author: Ishani Ganguli
description: When most people look at lobsters, they see dinner. Eve Marder saw a key to the theoretical underpinnings of animal behaviour. Ishani Ganguli reports.
title: Neuroscience: A gut feeling

author: Alison Abbott
description: Is blasting into a river bluff any way to do palaeontology? Alison Abbott reports on an unusual expedition into the Alaskan wilderness in search of the bones of polar dinosaurs.
title: Palaeontology: Tunnel vision

author: Daemon Fairless
description: M. S. Swaminathan transformed agriculture in India in the 1960s. Now Daemon Fairless finds him at the heart of another high-tech scheme to help the rural poor.
title: From wheat to web: Children of the revolution

author: Rex Dalton
description: Under the rubble of war-torn Afghanistan lie natural resources worth billions. Rex Dalton reports from Kabul on the scientists risking their lives to see them developed for the good of the country.
title: Geology: Mine games

author: Nick Lane
description: The nitrogen cycle rarely features in the grim litany of things at risk from global warming. Nick Lane reports on research that might change this ? with grave consequences for ocean chemistry.
title: Climate change: What's in the rising tide?

author: Brendan Maher
description: Despite a training in clinical genetics, Hugh Rienhoff didn't know what was wrong with his daughter. So, as he tells Brendan Maher, he set about finding out.
title: Personal genomics: His daughter's DNA

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: How do nuclear inspectors know when all is not as they are told? Geoff Brumfiel joins some inspectors-in-training as they learn the ropes at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.
title: Non-proliferation: School of Nukes

author: Daemon Fairless
description: India, like many countries, has high hopes for jatropha as a biofuel source, but little is known about how to make it a successful crop. Daemon Fairless digs for the roots of a new enthusiasm.
title: Biofuel: The little shrub that could - maybe

author: Alison Abbott
description: International collaboration and a can-do spirit have allowed some Russian scientists to flourish. Alison Abbott watches an extraordinary field test for mutant mice in the Russian wilderness.
title: Behavioural Genetics: A question of survival

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: The Russian Academy of Sciences has resisted pressure from czarists and communists. Can it thwart the reforms planned by Putin's government? Quirin Schiermeier reports.
title: Russian science: The battle for Russia's brains

author: Brendan Maher
description: Can a stage spectacular based on a TV documentary bring science to life and please the punters too? Brendan Maher joins a palaeontologist to watch the dinosaurs walk.
title: Bringing the past to life

author: Jane Qiu
description: China's railway to Tibet is an engineering marvel or an environmental menace — or perhaps both. Jane Qiu takes a ride to find out.
title: Riding on the roof of the world

author: Heidi Ledford
description: As several lucrative protein-based drugs are poised to go off patent, makers of biopharmaceuticals argue that their products are too complex to be reproduced as generics. Heidi Ledford investigates how close 'biosimilar' drugs can get to the original.
title: The same but different

author: David Cyranoski
description: The world's biggest, best-equipped research drilling vessel is about to set off on its first scientific voyage. David Cyranoski previews its quest to catch a formidable earthquake in the act.
title: In the zone

author: Navroz Patel
description: Particle accelerators that use plasma technology promise to shake up the fields of high-energy particle physics and cancer treatment. Challenges remain, but smaller, cheaper machines are within reach. Navroz Patel reports.
title: The plasma revolution

author: John Whitfield
description: Above ground, plants compete for life-giving sunlight, but below the surface a more complex picture emerges. John Whitfield explores the role of mycorrhizae in plant ecology.
title: Underground networking

author: Rex Dalton
description: The whole world felt the effects of the dinosaur-killing mass extinction 65 million years ago. But a spot in Colorado may have the best record of it. Rex Dalton reports from Denver.
title: Time traps

author: Jerry Guo
description: Dubious science and looming legalization of the tiger trade threaten to derail China's efforts to save the Siberian tiger. Jerry Guo goes to the world's largest tiger-breeding facility to investigate.
title: Year of the tiger

author: Brendan Maher
description: Physicists interested in the mechanics of single molecules are helping open one of the blackest boxes in biology. Brendan Maher discovers how the disciplines are working together.
title: Spring theory

author: David Chandler
description: When it was trying to catapult satellites into orbit the private launch business didn't get very far. Can it do better now that it's focused on giving the rich the ride of their life, asks David Chandler.
title: Dreams of the new space race

author: Erika Check
description: Researchers in San Francisco have findings that suggest a whole new side to RNA interference. Erika Check reports on their attempts to make a revolutionary field more revolutionary still.
title: Hitting the on switch

author: Emma Marris
description: Elephant populations are soaring in some parts of Africa. Emma Marris discovers there's no single way to fit them in amid the people.
title: Making room

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: Space exploration usually means leaving Earth's orbit. But chemists are now burrowing inside solids to open new vistas. Katharine Sanderson reports from the internal frontier.
title: Space invaders

author: Corinna Wu
description: For 30 years scientists have believed that there are no organic molecules in the martian soil. Will NASA's Phoenix probe prove them right or wrong, asks Corinna Wu.
title: Space exploration: Secrets of the martian soil

author: K. S. Jayaraman
description: India's new Ministry of Earth Sciences is at the helm of ambitious plans to advance deep-sea and polar research. K. S. Jayaraman reports.
title: Steaming ahead

author: Claire Ainsworth
description: No longer just cellular janitors, cilia are making a clean sweep for biological greatness. Claire Ainsworth explores how they may hold the secret of multicellular development.
title: Tails of the unexpected

author: Heidi Ledford
description: The ethics committees that oversee research done in humans have been attacked from all sides. Heidi Ledford recounts the struggle to come up with alternatives.
title: Trial and error

author: Michael Hopkin
description: A project that gives Congolese pygmies new ways to tell logging companies about the trees that are important to them, and their own radio station to discuss community issues, is really putting their interests on the map, says Michael Hopkin.
title: Mark of respect

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Alan Krensky has been put in charge of a controversial new office responsible for charting the progress of the NIH Roadmap for Medical Research. Meredith Wadman catches up with him in his first few days on the job.
title: The map man

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Why is dark energy, hailed as a breakthrough when discovered a decade ago, proving so frustrating to the scientists who study it?
title: A constant problem

author: Nick Lane
description: Studies of mass extinctions tend to emphasize the sheer scope of the carnage. But subtle differences between the species that died and those that survived can be crucial, finds Nick Lane.
title: Reading the book of death

author: Mark Buchanan
description: Fifty years ago, a physics student dissatisfied with the standard view of quantum mechanics came up with a radical new interpretation. Mark Buchanan reports on the ensuing debate.
title: See me here, see me there

author: Daemon Fairless
description: How did a little Spanish province become one of the world's wind-energy giants? Daemon Fairless reports.
title: Energy-Go-Round

author: Kris Novak
description: Smoking was banned in Californian bars a decade ago, and this week England follows suit. But Kris Novak finds that epidemiologists are still arguing about the effects of second-hand smoke.
title: Out from the haze

author: Josie Glausiusz
description: From acid mine drainage to the bowels of the Earth, Josie Glausiusz reports how researchers are taking great pains to grow recalcitrant bacteria.
title: Extreme culture

author: Andreas Trabesinger
description: Can motor racing go green? Andreas Trabesinger asked Max Mosley, head of Formula 1, how he wants the sport to develop energy-efficient technology that will also work in road cars.
title: Power games

author: Philip Ball
description: When two objects separated by a vacuum are barely a whisker apart, a strange attraction comes into play. Philip Ball meets the physicists who are trying to make something out of nothing.
title: Feel the force

author: Dan Jones
description: Is there wisdom to be found in repugnance? Or is disgust 'the nastiest of all emotions', offering nothing but support to prejudice? Dan Jones looks at the repellant side of human nature.
title: The depths of disgust

author: Carl Gierstorfer
description: Brought up in the Congo basin, Jonas Eriksson has worked through a war and battled poachers to help reveal the secrets of bonobo societies. Carl Gierstorfer reports.
title: Peaceful primates, violent acts

author: Alison Abbott
description: Long a symbol of East German pride, the Charité medical school is flourishing in the twenty-first-century shake-up of German universities. Alison Abbott reports.
title: A beacon of reform

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: How the oceans mix their waters is key to understanding future climate change. Yet scientists have a long way to go to unravel the mysteries of the deep. Quirin Schiermeier reports.
title: Churn, churn, churn

author: Kendall Powell
description: No longer viewed as inert packets of energy, fat cells are two-faced masterminds of metabolism. Kendall Powell weighs up the differences between 'fat' fat cells and thin ones.
title: The two faces of fat

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Quantum cryptography is theoretically unbreakable, yet a handful of physicists are finding ways to hack into its secrets. Geoff Brumfiel finds out how.
title: Seeking absolute security

author: Eric Sorensen
description: When you win a Nobel prize, you become much in demand. Eric Sorensen takes a look at how laureates decide which worthy causes to lend their name to.
title: Signing on

author: Alison Abbott
description: It is 50 years since Arvid Carlsson showed dopamine to be a neurotransmitter. Alison Abbott profiles a chemical and its champion.
title: The molecular wake-up call

author: Rex Dalton
description: A controversial new idea suggests that a big space rock exploded on or above North America at the end of the last ice age. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Blast in the past?

author: Erika Check
description: Biomedical scientists want funding; private foundations want cures. Erika Check hears the joys and tensions that arise when the two hook up.
title: Love or money

author: Lucy Odling-Smee
description: Flush with Microsoft's fortune, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is the largest charitable foundation in the United States. Tadataka Yamada, executive director of its Global Health Program, tells Lucy Odling-Smee how the organization aims to save lives with its wealth.
title: The giving machine

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Wealthy philanthropists and private foundations are supporting biomedical research on a grand scale. Meredith Wadman asks what they get for their money.
title: State of the donation

author: Emma Marris
description: Why do chemists make compounds that could blow up in their faces? Emma Marris finds out... from a safe distance.
title: Teetering on the edge

author: Helen Pearson
description: Imaging fluorescent molecules in live cells is revolutionizing cell biology. But a pretty image is not necessarily a good one, and many biologists are learning this the hard way, finds Helen Pearson.
title: The good, the bad and the ugly

author: Oliver Morton
description: Long marginalized as a dubious idea, altering the climate through 'geoengineering' has staged something of a comeback. Oliver Morton reports.
title: Is this what it takes to save the world?

author: Ichiko Fuyuno
description: Neuroscientist Ryuta Kawashima promotes the idea that computer games can boost the ageing brain — but others in the field remain sceptical. Ichiko Fuyuno investigates.
title: Brain craze

author: Haim Watzman
description: Archaeologists are unearthing remarkable finds in Jerusalem. But the digs have sparked an argument over who should run the site and present the results to the public. Haim Watzman reports.
title: Deep divisions

author: Michael Cherry
description: Two institutes on opposite sides of South Africa are intent on tackling HIV. But they are separated by more than geographical distance, finds Michael Cherry.
title: A tale of two centres

author: Erika Check
description: Antibody therapies have had more than their fair share of crashes. But designers are at work on faster, fancier new models, finds Erika Check.
title: Pimp my antibody

author: Colin Macilwain
