description: A shift in population, money and political influence to America's 'sunbelt states' is helping to reshape its research universities. The first of two features looks at the far-reaching ambitions of Arizona State University. The second asks whether a rush to create extra medical schools could spread the region's resources too thinly.
title: The Arizona experiment

author: Declan Butler
description: ...or have its failings been greatly exaggerated? Declan Butler finds out.
title: Is French science in decline...

author: Amanda Haag
description: Members of the public are taking to the streets to spread Al Gore's message of climate crisis. Amanda Haag meets the foot soldiers of global warming.
title: Al's Army

author: Jim Giles
description: African communities have been adapting to climate change for millennia. Jim Giles reports on the strategies that seem most effective.
title: How to survive a warming world

author: Gabrielle Walker
description: Despite years of speculation, little can be said for sure about the future of the Arctic's permafrost. But that's no grounds for complacency, reports Gabrielle Walker.
title: A world melting from the top down

author: Rex Dalton
description: Philadelphia's venerable natural history museum is teetering on the brink of financial disaster. A new president recently took the helm, but can he save one of America's great institutions? Rex Dalton reports.
title: Endangered collections

author: Jeff Kanipe
description: Vast stellar nurseries, clouds that dwarf the Solar System and lurking swarms of black holes. Jeff Kanipe probes the unfolding mysteries at the heart of the Milky Way.
title: A long time ago, in a galaxy not so far away

author: David Cyranoski
description: Can a vast monoculture plantation be at the forefront of biodiversity protection? David Cyranoski meets conservation biologists who hope to save species by making peace with the enemy.
title: Logging: the new conservation

author: Jo Marchant
description: How much can geometry and mathematics reveal about paintings? How far should hidden meanings be trusted in art? Jo Marchant investigates the latest, and possibly most controversial, interpretation of a Renaissance masterpiece.
title: A leap of faith

author: Jim Giles
description: Many Iraqi academics have escaped death threats only to find that their qualifications are obsolete and immigration authorities are unsympathetic. Jim Giles hears their stories.
title: Lives in limbo

author: Emma Marris
description: The US military is getting a lot of flak for the way it treats wounded soldiers returning from Iraq. Emma Marris reports on the advances in medical care that are helping to bring them home.
title: The war against wounds

author: Katharine Sanderson
description: The buzz over invisibility cloaks is fun — while it lasts. But metamaterials are likely to transform optics through more mundane applications. Katharine Sanderson reports.
title: Unexpected tricks of the light

author: Brendan Borrell
description: Professional taxonomists often bristle at non-professionals who name new species without going through peer review. But are amateur naturalists really bad for science? Brendan Borrell reports.
title: The big name hunters

author: Henry Nicholls
description: Although Linnaeus is best known for his botany and taxonomy, he was also an anatomist — and a keeper of pets. Henry Nicholls tells the story of Sjupp the raccoon.
title: The royal raccoon from Swedesboro

author: Emma Marris
description: For some, species are simply the things you save; but for taxonomists, the concept is much more complex. Emma Marris asks whether Linnaeus's legacy is cut out for conservation.
title: The species and the specious

author: John Whitfield
description: Updating the tree of life needs both the skills of evolutionary biologists and the data from genome-crunchers — the two ignore each other at their peril. John Whitfield reports.
title: We are family

author: Nicola Jones
description: Air bubbles trapped in the Antarctic ice sheet could yield precious information about Earth's climate more than a million years ago. But to access this record, scientists first have to climb one of the coldest peaks on Earth. Nicola Jones reports.
title: Buried treasure

author: Alexandra Witze
description: The rocks of Antarctica are obscured literally, and sometimes scientifically, by its ice. But drilling efforts are now showing what we can learn from the hard stuff. Alexandra Witze reports.
title: School of rock

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Every summer the Arctic Ocean loses more ice — and it could all be gone within decades. Quirin Schiermeier looks at how the vanishing summer ice affects those living in the north.
title: The new face of the Arctic

author: Helen Pearson
description: From a New Jersey beauty parlour to cutting-edge genetics by way of her own alopecia, Angela Christiano's life has all been tied up with hair. Helen Pearson meets a woman whose head is full of the stuff that covers it.
title: The roots of accomplishment

author: Ed Gerstner
description: Physicists are planning lasers powerful enough to rip apart the fabric of space and time. Ed Gerstner is impressed.
title: Extreme light

author: Declan Butler
description: An Italian scientist revived the hunt for the mafia's boss of bosses. Declan Butler reports.
title: Ghost buster

author: Heidi Ledford
description: Hundreds of orchid species lure their pollinators with the promise of sex, only to send them away unfulfilled. Heidi Ledford looks at how dishonesty gives them the evolutionary edge.
title: The flower of seduction

author: David Cyranoski
description: How did a mud volcano come to destroy an Indonesian town? David Cyranoski reports from Sidoarjo.
title: Muddy waters

author: Jennifer Ouellette
description: One half of a physics couple that met online, Jennifer Ouellette seeks some advice from married scientists on how to handle both long-distance and up-close relationships, while juggling career and family. Can love survive?
title: When two worlds collide

author: Mark Schrope
description: Could a change in the dining habits of orcas crash an ecosystem? Mark Schrope reports on a mystery that reveals how little we know of the oceans.
title: Killer in the kelp

author: Apoorva Mandavilli
description: How often does independent research change laws as well as minds? A lobby group in Delhi is forcing the Indian government into new regulations. Apoorva Mandavilli meets its leader.
title: A breath of fresh air

author: Ned Stafford
description: Rising carbon dioxide levels should increase crop yields. But what if their effect on the nutritional value of our food is less benign, asks Ned Stafford.
title: The other greenhouse effect

author: Bruce Goldman
description: Extracting a cell from a budding human embryo can expose genetic defects, but does it actually help generate more healthy babies? Bruce Goldman investigates.
title: The first cut

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Three years ago, President George W. Bush told NASA to return American astronauts to the Moon. Geoff Brumfiel reports on how far they have got.
title: Where 24 men have gone before

author: Thomas Hayden
description: Is parachuting into the Amazonian jungle any way to save an ecosystem? One team of biologists thinks so. Thomas Hayden joined them on a trip to Peru to find out what they do.
title: Ground force

author: Philip Ball
description: By 2020 the semiconductor industry wants a memory device that can store a trillion bits of information in an area the size of a postage stamp. As companies race towards this goal, chemists are coming up with an unusual approach. Philip Ball reports.
title: A switch in time

author: Tom Siegfried
description: Taking hormones to replace those lost during menopause helps many women with their symptoms, yet it may also cause cognitive decline. Could the age at which hormones are taken determine whether they will be beneficial or harmful? Tom Siegfried reports.
title: It's all in the timing

author: Michael Cherry
description: Next week, African leaders will come together to talk about science and technology at a summit in Ethiopia. This presents an opportunity to allot some foreign aid and, if they get it right, to launch projects that will draw further donations from abroad, says Michael Cherry.
title: All eyes on Addis

author: Mark Buchanan
description: Statistics have the power to trip everyone up — including judges and juries. Even when extra care is taken to get the numbers right in court, confusion often reigns. Mark Buchanan reports.
title: Conviction by numbers

author: Alison Abbott
description: Programming a robot to think like an insect is tough, finds Alison Abbott, but it could help breed machines as manoeuvrable as flies.
title: Working out the bugs

author: Navroz Patel
description: Life is full of events that are basically games, from paying for a meal to bidding in an auction. Can incorporating a quantum strategy into the rule book increase your chances of winning? Navroz Patel reports.
title: States of play

author: Colin Macilwain
description: Containing a potential HIV explosion in the strife-torn Niger delta is a tough job — but circumstances are forcing the oil and gas industries to confront it. Colin Macilwain reports.
title: On the Brink

author: Jim Giles
description: Manipulating society has traditionally been the preserve of politicians and the gods. Does the current boom in virtual worlds give social scientists and economists an opportunity to join them? Jim Giles investigates.
title: Life's a game

author: Alexandra Witze
description: Optimists see oil gushing for decades; pessimists see the planet's energy future already drying up. Alexandra Witze reports.
title: That's oil, folks...

author: Erika Check
description: The development of lactose tolerance in sub-Saharan Africa is a fascinating tale of genetic convergence, reports Erika Check.
title: How Africa learned to love the cow

author: Helen Pearson
description: Ultraendurance racers torture their bodies and minds to achieve near-impossible physical feats. Is it an exceptional genetic make-up or the vestiges of human evolution? Helen Pearson reports.
title: Freaks of nature?

author: Mark Schrope
description: Kerry Black travelled the world in search of the best surf spots. Then he decided to build them himself — on land. Mark Schrope meets the maverick oceanographer.
title: Creating the perfect wave

author: Kerri Smith
description: Researchers aren't the only ones who concern themselves with animal welfare in the lab. Vets are asked regularly to monitor and care for these animals — a role that can call for some difficult decisions. Kerri Smith talks to Sarah Wolfensohn, head of veterinary services at the University of Oxford, UK, about the challenges and conflicts presented by caring for experimental animals.
title: caught in the middle

author: Emma Marris
description: Many scientists have nuanced views on animal research. But they are rarely heard, says Emma Marris.
title: Grey Matters

author: David Cyranoski
description: Primate researchers have long faced violent protests over their work. But in some countries, regulatory obstacles are taking a greater toll. David Cyranoski meets European scientists who feel that bureaucratic pressures are closing their labs.
title: Primates in the frame

author: Jane Qiu
description: Coordination and integration of the results of animal research are an ever-increasing challenge. Jane Qiu finds out what happens when big biology meets a small rodent.
title: Mighty mouse

author: Michael Cherry
description: Khotso Mokhele, formerly in charge of developing research in South Africa, talks to Michael Cherry about the role that science is playing in the nation's development.
title: Conscious of change

author: Michael Hopkin
description: The biggest project in the history of ecology is nearing its dawn. Can its organizers pull off the seemingly impossible and unite a disparate field behind its vision to observe the ecosystems of the United States? Michael Hopkin reports.
title: Spying on nature

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: Philosophers since Aristotle have puzzled over the meaning of happiness. Tony Reichhardt asks what scientists, psychologists and economists can bring to the topic. Are we any closer to being able to quantify joy?
title: A measure of happiness

author: David Cyranoski
description: When landfills overflow, governments need new ways to deal with garbage. David Cyranoski visits a plant in Japan where plasma technology is turning waste into energy.
title: One man's trash...

author: Trevor Stokes
description: What makes the perfect protein purification or the right reagent reaction? Trevor Stokes investigates the weird world of good-luck lab charms.
title: Charmed, I'm sure

author: Helen Pearson
description: There's more than one way to read a stretch of DNA, finds Helen Pearson — and we need to understand them all.
title: Codes and enigmas

author: Jane Qiu
description: Working out whether premature babies feel pain has important implications for child development, says Jane Qiu.
title: Does it hurt?

author: Jenny Hogan
description: Most astronomers head for remote mountain-tops or deserts to study the cosmos. Jenny Hogan meets a confident team set up on a patch of farmland in a crowded corner of mainland Europe.
title: Dutch courage

author: Declan Butler
description: Mostafa Moin is a paediatrician and medical researcher who has served as Iran's minister for higher education and for science. He was a reformist candidate in Iran's presidential election last year, which was won by religious conservative Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. Declan Butler asks Moin about the prospects for science in Iran.
title: Q&A The reformer

author: Declan Butler
description: Statistics on scientific investment and performance are lacking across the Muslim world. Declan Butler analyses the best of what is available.
title: The data gap

author: Jim Giles
description: The wealthy Arab states offer scant support for science and technology. Jim Giles finds out whether this indifference to research is likely to change.
title: Oil rich, science poor

author: John Whitfield
description: Understanding the trade-offs involved for plants making leaves promises fresh insights on every scale from the plant to the planet, finds John Whitfield
title: The cost of leafing

author: Trevor Stokes
description: Research suggests that consuming soil may have more health implications than one might expect. Trevor Stokes sieves through the reasons why people include dirt in their diet.
title: The earth-eaters

author: Ehsan Masood
description: Islamist political parties are taking over from secular ones across the Muslim world. What does this mean for science at home and scientific cooperation with the West? Ehsan Masood investigates.
title: An Islamist revolution

author: Jo Marchant
description: The ancient Antikythera Mechanism doesn't just challenge our assumptions about technology transfer over the ages — it gives us fresh insights into history itself.
title: In search of lost time

author: Emma Marris
description: Is the cure for cancer lurking beneath the waves? Emma Marris plunges into the chemistry of marine natural products.
title: Drugs from the deep

author: Nick Lane
description: There's a fight going on inside all our cells for each breath of air. Nick Lane sheds therapeutic light on the implications for cancer and degenerative diseases.
title: Power games

author: Rex Dalton
description: The cheerful leaves of the poinsettia could be hiding an unwelcome visitor this festive season. Rex Dalton goes in search of the whitefly, a potentially devastating pest.
title: The Christmas Invasion

author: Henry Nicholls
description: Darwin is the latest eminent scientist to get an online archive. How do these undertakings change our understanding of history, asks Henry Nicholls.
title: A life online

author: Natasha Bolognesi
description: AIDS treatment in South Africa is often a tug-of-war between clinicians and traditional healers. Natasha Bolognesi meets a woman who is uniquely qualified to heal the rift.
title: A question of trust

author: Erika Check
description: It started life as an anaesthetic, then became a psychedelic club drug. Now researchers think ketamine could hold the key to understanding and treating depression, says Erika Check.
title: Comfortably numb

author: Mark Schrope
description: What can pirates' journals and centuries-old cookbooks teach modern-day ecologists? Mark Schrope meets the researchers who trawl history books for deeper insights into marine ecosystems.
title: The real sea change

author: Jonah Lehrer
description: We're selfish and rational — that's what classical economics says. But play parlour games with brain scanners and you'll find we're pulled in different directions when it comes to money. Jonah Lehrer reports.
title: Driven to market

author: Britta Danger
description: Can an advertising executive write an accurate thriller about science? Britta Danger talks to a German author who thinks he has pulled it off.
title: A novel reality

author: Emma Marris
description: What drives environmental activists to fire-bomb laboratories? Emma Marris investigates a radical fringe of the US green movement.
title: In the name of nature

author: Virginia Hughes
description: Hagia Sophia has stood four-square in Istanbul for more than 1,500 years. Virginia Hughes finds out how this venerable building has resisted the area's numerous earthquakes.
title: Hagia Sophia: Shaken, not stirred

author: Mike Shanahan
description: Science journalists in the developing world face unique stumbling blocks, even as some of the biggest science stories unfold around them. Mike Shanahan reports.
title: Fighting a reporting battle

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: US astronomers are renowned for getting together and choosing their projects as a group. But just as these tactics are catching on in other fields, some say the astronomy process is grinding to a halt. Geoff Brumfiel investigates.
title: Decadal surveys: Wishing for the stars

author: Amanda Haag
description: Interdisciplinary research is the new buzzword, but does a grounding in different disciplines really make you better at solving problems? Amanda Haag joins an experiment to find out.
title: A testing experience

author: Rex Dalton
description: Maurice Taieb laid the groundwork for the discovery of Lucy, the most famous fossil human ancestor. Rex Dalton meets the Tunisian-born geologist who prefers the desert to the limelight.
title: The history man

author: Helen Pearson
description: We've been told to eat less and move more to battle the growing obesity epidemic. But could getting more shuteye also be a way to fight the fat? Helen Pearson investigates.
title: Sleep it off

author: Jeff Kanipe
description: Physicists and climate scientists have long argued over whether changes to the Sun affect the Earth's climate? A cloud chamber could help clear up the dispute, reports Jeff Kanipe.
title: A cosmic connection

author: Henry Nicholls
description: No one has seen a dodo in three and a half centuries, but that hasn't stopped the bizarre speculation about this extinct bird. Henry Nicholls investigates whether recent excavations in Mauritius could reveal the real creature.
title: Digging for dodo

author: Jacqueline Ruttimann
description: The rising level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is making the world's oceans more acidic. Jacqueline Ruttimann reports on the potentially catastrophic effect this could have on marine creatures.
title: Sick seas

author: Helen Pilcher
description: IVF isn't something most Westerners associate with Africa. But low-cost methods are urgently needed to treat the misery of infertility rampant on the continent, says Helen Pilcher.
title: Fertility on a shoestring

author: Apoorva Mandavilli
description: Can everyone use technology creatively? Engineers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology think so and have launched 'Fab Labs' around the world to prove it. Apoorva Mandavilli reports.
title: Make anything, anywhere

author: Kendall Powell
description: Changes in the structure of children's brains may account for some of the risky business of adolescence, Kendall Powell finds.
title: How does the teenage brain work?

author: Alison Abbott
description: Is targeting cancer stem cells a way to finish tumours off once and for all — or just the latest in a long line of false dawns? Alison Abbott looks at a debate that's generating both heat and light.
title: The root of the problem

author: Laura Spinney
description: The detection of cancer at an early stage in its development can be life-saving. With research efforts under way to find better methods to detect minuscule tumours, Laura Spinney finds out how near some of these cancer 'biomarkers' are to the clinic.
title: Caught in time

author: Carina Dennis
description: Much of what we know about cancer comes from studying mice, and potential therapies are tested in the animals. But the differences between the species can scupper the best laid plans of researchers and drug companies, reports Carina Dennis.
title: Off by a whisker

author: Erika Check
description: Some feared that widespread use of AIDS treatments in Africa would encourage drug resistance, with globally disastrous consequences. But there's no crisis yet, reports Erika Check.
title: Staying the course

author: Philip Ball
description: Chemistry is a key component in all the scientific disciplines. But does that mean it is nothing more than a handy tool — or are there still major chemical questions to crack? Philip Ball finds out.
title: What chemists want to know

author: Jenny Hogan
description: Faster, safer and easier to control — chemical reactions in microreactors are taking off in the lab. Now industry is being seduced by the charms of the lab on a chip. Jenny Hogan investigates.
title: A little goes a long way

author: Erika Check
description: The United States has embarked on a huge effort to try to track the H5N1 avian flu virus in birds migrating into the country. But is surveillance more urgently needed elsewhere? Erika Check reports.
title: On border patrol

author: Jim Giles
description: The idea that readers should be able to replicate published scientific results is seen as the bedrock of modern science. But what if replication proves difficult or impossible? Jim Giles tracks the fate of one group of papers.
title: The trouble with replication

author: Rex Dalton
description: DNA extracted from bones could shed light on what happened when our ancestors crossed paths with Neanderthals. But not everyone can get the fossils out of the ground, as Rex Dalton learns.
title: Decoding our cousins

author: Colin Macilwain
description: The White House is trying to reform environmental and health regulation across the board. But it is doing so very quietly. Colin Macilwain takes a look behind the scenes.
title: Safe and sound?

author: Alison Abbott
description: Implants in the brain could one day help paralysed people move robotic arms and legs. But first, scientists need to work out how our brains know where our limbs are, says Alison Abbott.
title: In search of the sixth sense

author: Alexandra Witze
description: Plate tectonics has created oceans and pushed up mountain ranges. But when did the process that shapes the planet get going? Alexandra Witze joins the geologists debating the issue.
title: The start of the world as we know it

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: US nuclear weapons scientists are designing a warhead that is meant to be ‘reliable’ without ever having been tested. Geoff Brumfiel asks whether it could renew the United States' ageing stockpile.
title: The next nuke

author: Sarah Tomlin
description: An economist believes that a five-year aid effort in a dozen villages across Africa can teach the world how to defeat poverty. Sarah Tomlin reports on the project's progress in Rwanda.
title: Harvest of hope

author: Alison Abbott
description: There's more to science at the movies than Lex Luthor's attempts to synthesize kryptonite. In the first of two features on film, John Whitfield looks at how a cinematographic technique can provide insights into the perception of reality. In the second, Alison Abbott meets Ben Heisenberg, a director whose first film is a taut moral fable of laboratory life.
title: From microscope to multiplex - Betrayal at the bench

author: John Whitfield
description: There's more to science at the movies than Lex Luthor's attempts to synthesize kryptonite. In the first of two features on film, John Whitfield looks at how a cinematographic technique can provide insights into the perception of reality. In the second, Alison Abbott meets Ben Heisenberg, a director whose first film is a taut moral fable of laboratory life.
title: From microscope to multiplex - An MRI scanner darkly

author: Erika Check
description: Tigers are teetering on the verge of extinction and human contact in their habitat could be their greatest threat. Erika Check investigates whether local people can live alongside India's big cats.
title: The tiger's retreat

author: Laura Spinney
description: Reducing your calorie intake makes you live longer — if you're a rat or a worm. Laura Spinney asks whether the same holds for humans — and if it does, whether the benefits could be put in a pill.
title: Eat your cake and have it

author: Gabrielle Walker
description: Could climate change run away with itself? Gabrielle Walker looks at the balance of evidence.
title: The tipping point of the iceberg

author: Philip Ball
description: Some economists had hoped that physicists might shake up the rigid theories typical of mainstream economics. But so far, they're unimpressed by physicists' handling of the markets. Philip Ball reports.
title: Culture Crash

author: Garry Hamilton
description: Viruses are often thought of as simple creatures. But their staggering diversity and genetic promiscuity could make them the most creative force in evolution, says Garry Hamilton.
title: The gene weavers

author: Emma Marris
description: Scientists say they gas mice and rats with carbon dioxide because it is humane. It's also simple, cheap and keeps their hands clean. Emma Marris analyses the final seconds of the lab rodents' life.
title: An easy way out?

author: Rex Dalton
description: Costa Rica's flagship conservation institute needs help. Can a new deal with industry save it? Rex Dalton investigates.
title: Cashing in on the rich coast

author: Alexandra Witze
description: Scientists and policymakers are battling over whether global warming is making hurricanes more destructive. Alexandra Witze ventures into the heart of the storm.
title: Bad weather ahead

author: Stuart Clark
description: The Sun occasionally hurls streams of particles towards Earth, where they can wreak havoc with satellites. Predicting these solar storms is hard, but some physicists believe we're about to face the biggest bout of solar flares in years. Stuart Clark reports.
title: The dark side of the Sun

author: Helen Pearson
description: The idea of genes as beads on a DNA string is fast fading. Protein-coding sequences have no clear beginning or end and RNA is a key part of the information package, reports Helen Pearson.
title: What is a gene?

author: Apoorva Mandavilli
description: Prevailing wisdom says the adult brain cannot learn to see if it had no visual stimulation during childhood, but blind people in India seem to be breaking all the rules. Apoorva Mandavilli reports.
title: Look and learn

author: Nick Lane
description: Among their many talents, bacteria are the world's best electrochemists, creating a life-powering flow of electrons in a startling range of conditions. In the first of two features, Nick Lane asks what limits, if any, constrain this ability. In the second, Charlotte Schubert meets the people trying to put this microbial ingenuity to practical use.
title: Batteries not included What can't bacteria do?

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: The Arctic is the bellwether of climate change, which shows up there first and fastest. Quirin Schiermeier visits ecologists struggling to keep up.
title: On thin ice

author: Jane Qiu
description: To correctly ‘play’ the DNA score in our genome, cells must read another notation that overlays it — the epigenetic code. A global effort to decode it is now in the making, reports Jane Qiu.
title: Unfinished symphony

author: Jacqueline Ruttimann
description: Does the respected US National Institutes of Health meet the needs of young postdoc researchers? Jacqueline Ruttimann investigates.
title: It's a postdoc's life

author: Erika Check
description: Elias Zerhouni has one of the biggest jobs in biomedical research — running the massive US National Institutes of Health. But is he leading the agency up the right path? Erika Check examines his tenure.
title: Facing the opposition

author: Helen Pilcher
description: Facing a moral dilemma in the lab? No reason to panic. Helen Pilcher meets the academic troubleshooters who promise a quick answer to any ethical problem.
title: Dial ‘E’ for ethics

author: Michael Bawaya
description: Archaeologists are bringing past worlds vividly to life on the computer screen. But are the high-tech graphics helping science, or are they just pretty pictures? Michael Bawaya takes a look.
title: Digital digs

author: David Cyranoski
description: Geophysicists are racing to understand a recently discovered phenomenon deep in the Earth. David Cyranoski joins them.
title: Magical mantle tour

author: Naomi Lubick
description: In 1906, a great earthquake destroyed San Francisco, and galvanized US seismologists. Naomi Lubick looks back at the event that changed the country's geological scene.
title: Breaking new ground

author: Emma Marris
description: In a world of declining biodiversity, botanical gardens are coming into their own — both as storehouses of rare plants and skills, and increasingly as centres of molecular research. Emma Marris reports.
title: Gardens in full bloom

author: Samir S. Patel
description: The floods are getting worse in Tuvalu. As scientists argue over climate change and struggle to measure rising seas, Samir S. Patel meets the locals of this tiny island nation.
title: A sinking feeling

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: The global future of nuclear power may rest in large part on local politics, reports Geoff Brumfiel.
title: Chernobyl and the future: Forward planning

author: Jim Giles
description: Once touted as too cheap to meter, nuclear power has become too costly to build. But the economics may be shifting, finds Jim Giles.
title: Chernobyl and the future: when the price is right

author: Kendall Powell
description: The two Roger Pielkes can be obstructionist pains in the neck, say their colleagues. So why is this likeable father–son pair such a welcome addition to the debate on global climate change? Kendall Powell clears the air.
title: The son also rises

author: Nick Lane
description: Many of the genes affecting mitochondria — tiny energy suppliers of cells — reside in the cell nucleus. Nick Lane joins the hunt for these sequences that may underpin diseases such as diabetes.
title: Powerhouse of disease

author: Declan Butler
description: Tiny computers that constantly monitor ecosystems, buildings and even human bodies could turn science on its head. Declan Butler investigates.
title: Everything, everywhere

author: Jenny Hogan
description: A series of mental challenges is helping physicists to prepare for the strange data they may get when the next particle accelerator goes live. Jenny Hogan joins the work-out.
title: Let the games begin

author: Alison Abbott
description: Alison Abbott talks to the man who wants theoretical chemistry to ease political strife in the Middle East.
title: Make a strong bond

author: Jim Giles
description: Studies of medical literature are confirming what many suspected — reporters of clinical trials do not always play straight. Jim Giles talks to those pushing for a fairer deal.
title: Stacking the deck

author: Michael Hopkin
description: Ecologists paid by industry to assess the effects of businesses on the environment are often accused of selling their souls. But isn't scientific expertise exactly what is needed? Michael Hopkin investigates.
title: Caught between shores

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: The cost of the James Webb Space Telescope could cripple US astronomy. Tony Reichhardt takes a closer look.
title: Is the next big thing too big?

author: Jenny Hogan
description: Atomic force microscopes have revolutionized the study of materials, but probing watery biological systems has proved more difficult. Jenny Hogan asks whether a fix is at hand.
title: Focus on the living

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Last autumn's deadly earthquake caught Pakistan's government and scientific community off guard. Now a handful of officials and academics are struggling to bring the country up to code. Geoff Brumfiel reports from the scene.
title: Shaking the foundations

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Some say that life began in fire. Hauke Trinks thinks it began in ice, and is bent on taking the hard route to prove it. Quirin Schiermeier tells the Arctic adventurer's tale.
title: The iceman of Svalbard

author: John Whitfield
description: Europe pumps large quantities of cash into schemes that encourage less-intensive farming. But, finds John Whitfield, some researchers are not sure what benefits they deliver.
title: How green was my subsidy?

author: Christina Reed
description: Teams of researchers are finding vents in ocean floors around the globe. Christina Reed follows the hunt for these extreme ecosystems.
title: Boiling points

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Scientists and medical doctors view research through different lenses — but the gulf in outlook between the two tribes isn't what it used to be. Meredith Wadman reports.
title: Them and us no longer

author: Declan Butler
description: Life happens in three dimensions, so why doesn't science? Declan Butler discovers that online tools, led by the Google Earth virtual globe, are changing the way we interact with spatial data.
title: The web-wide world

author: Alison Abbott
description: Fractal analysis has been used to assess the authenticity of paintings purporting to be the work of Jackson Pollock. Alison Abbott reports.
title: In the hands of a master

author: Alison Abbott
description: The first vaccine against Lyme disease was withdrawn because patients distrusted it. Should market forces be allowed to shape the next one, asks Alison Abbott.
title: Uphill Struggle

author: Carina Dennis
description: A horrible facial cancer is decimating the Tasmanian devil population. But researchers in Australia think they have found a way to save the species. Carina Dennis reports.
title: Time to raise the devil

author: Jeff Kanipe
description: Two decades after plans were set in motion for the world's most powerful ground-based telescope, astronomers are bracing themselves for a downgrade to curb escalating costs. Jeff Kanipe reports.
title: High and dry

author: Apoorva Mandavilli
description: SARS caught China unawares. But the ensuing struggle to characterize and contain the virus has put the country's work on infectious diseases back on target. Apoorva Mandavilli reports.
title: Open season

author: John Whitfield
description: Can reading the classics through Charles Darwin's spectacles reawaken literary study? John Whitfield reports.
title: Textual selection

author: Virginia Gewin
description: Soil microbes are notoriously hard to culture, so how can we make the ground yield its secrets? Virginia Gewin finds that genetic sequencing — of samples not species — may be the answer.
title: Discovery in the dirt

author: Rex Dalton
description: For decades, much of the early history of fish evolution was locked away in rocks in China. Rex Dalton tracks down the scientist who brought many of the remains to the surface.
title: Hooked on fossils

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: A collapse in ocean currents triggered by global warming could be catastrophic, but only now is the Atlantic circulation being properly monitored. Quirin Schiermeier investigates.
title: A sea change

author: Ichiko Fuyuno
description: Japan's mission to collect a sample from a distant asteroid looks to have ended in failure. Ichiko Fuyuno investigates how the setback will affect Japan's struggling space programme.
title: A shot in the dark?

author: Roxanne Khamsi
description: A number of fatal brain diseases are linked to misfolded proteins, an effect researchers are mimicking in the lab. But as they generate new versions of these malformed molecules, could they be creating a monster? Roxanne Khamsi finds out.
title: The shape of things to come

author: John Whitfield
description: Could viruses have invented DNA as a way to sneak into cells? John Whitfield investigates.
title: Base invaders

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: A growing number of cosmologists and string theorists suspect the form of our Universe is little more than a coincidence. Are these harmless thought experiments, or a challenge to science itself? Geoff Brumfiel investigates.
title: Outrageous fortune

author: Rex Dalton
description: The Afar region of Ethiopia is littered with traces of the earliest humans. Rex Dalton gets on the trail with a team of devoted experts who just live for the next find.
title: Awash with fossils

author: Rex Dalton
description: A decade ago, the tequila industry was pummelled by plant diseases. Rex Dalton meets the scientists working to keep the blue agave diverse enough to survive.
title: Saving the agave

author: Siëlle Gramser
description: In the first of three Features looking at aspects of alcohol, Siëlle Gramser discovers how yeast first opened the floodgates of intoxication.
title: The party gene

author: Alexandra Witze
description: Winemakers in the United States are increasingly calling on the services of geologists to help refine their products. Alexandra Witze meets the scientists who are treading a path to the past.
title: The grapes of rock

author: Erika Check
description: Replanting coastal forests destroyed by last December's tsunami sounds like a good idea — especially if they protect against future storms. But such plans need nurturing if they are to succeed, Erika Check discovers.
title: Roots of recovery

author: Emma Marris
description: In the wake of Hurricane Katrina, coastal experts are trying to gauge the destruction to Louisiana's marshes. Emma Marris travels to the coast to learn what might be saved — and what might not.
title: The vanishing coast

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Natural disasters have wreaked havoc on the planet in the past twelve months, and some say that things will only get worse. Quirin Schiermeier assesses the world's growing vulnerability to catastrophe.
title: The chaos to come

author: Karen Fox
description: Next June, a $1.4-billion neutron-scattering facility will come online in the United States. Karen Fox finds out whether this machine really can breathe fresh life into the ageing Tennessee lab that is its home.
title: Back on track?

author: Erika Check
description: A new technique could allow doctors to spot hundreds of potential genetic problems in unborn babies. But is it too soon to put it to use? Erika Check finds out.
title: Screen test

author: Claire Ainsworth
description: A trial drug encourages cells to ignore the signs that stop them making faulty proteins. Sound dangerous? Claire Ainsworth discovers that it could be a cure for genetic disease.
title: Running the red light

author: Jim Giles
description: Google has launched another challenge to commercial search services — this time aimed at scientists. But is the new engine running as smoothly as its fans hope? Jim Giles investigates.
title: Start your engines

author: Andreas von Bubnoff
description: Despite clashes with publishers over copyright, Google's plan to make millions of books available online is turning the tide for efforts to digitize the world's literature. Andreas von Bubnoff tracks the demise of the printed page.
title: The real death of print

author: Declan Butler
description: At its best, academia is a marketplace of ideas. But many scientists are reluctant to embrace the latest web tools that would allow them to communicate their ideas in new ways, says Declan Butler.
title: Joint efforts

author: Gabrielle Walker
description: When darkness falls for Antarctica's long winter months, the sky becomes a spectacular canopy of stars. At one brand new base, astronomers are braving the extreme cold to build telescopes that they hope will rival space observatories. Gabrielle Walker investigates.
title: Seeing in the dark

author: Erika Check
description: Earlier this month, students from around the world locked horns in competition. Their challenge was to build functioning devices out of biological parts. Erika Check finds out how they got on.
title: Designs on life

author: Charles Petit
description: For decades, California has bucked the US trend of gobbling ever more electricity. But can the state pull off an even more ambitious goal and slash its greenhouse-gas emissions? Charles Petit finds out.
title: Power struggle

author: Emma Marris
description: The US government has adopted a tough approach to battling harmful exotic plants: specialist strike teams. But can they prevail? Emma Marris finds out it's not all black and white.
title: Shoot to kill

author: David Cyranoski
description: The Himalayas, roof of the world, are springing a leak. As the climate warms up, melting glaciers are threatening the livelihoods of millions. David Cyranoski reports.
title: The long-range forecast

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: A protest by Chinese graduate students at Yale University has revealed the plight of a vulnerable workforce in US labs. Geoff Brumfiel investigates.
title: Taking a stand

author: Carina Dennis
description: Could mice with faulty genes help us to understand the biology of psychiatric disease? Carina Dennis investigates.
title: All in the mind of a mouse

author: Jessica Ebert
description: Endangered languages often contain key linguistic insights found nowhere else. But the tongues are disappearing faster than scientists can document them. Jessica Ebert reports.
title: Tongue tied

author: Alison Abbott
description: Commercial and political pressures are pushing for a halt to the use of animals in toxicology tests in Europe. This change will also mean a move towards better science, says Alison Abbott.
title: More than a cosmetic change

author: Michael Cherry
description: This month South Africa will officially open the largest optical telescope in the Southern Hemisphere. But is the country ready to capitalize on its investment? Michael Cherry investigates.
title: Star of the south

author: Mark Schrope
description: Hurricanes can grow more intense in a matter of hours, but exactly why remains a mystery. Mark Schrope flies into the eye of a storm to investigate.
title: Winds of change

author: Helen Pilcher
description: It's a bizarre, toxin-filled microbe that could clean up sewage plants across the globe. Helen Pilcher gets on the trail of the anammox bacterium.
title: Pipe dreams

author: Alison Abbott
description: The flailing limbs of someone acting out their dreams in bed may not seem the obvious place to seek a cure for Parkinson's disease. But, as Alison Abbott finds out, this sleep disorder is shedding fresh light on the development of neurodegenerative disorders.
title: While you were sleeping

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Ignoring the mainstream, physicist Seth Putterman has a knack for bringing long-forgotten mysteries back to the fore. Geoff Brumfiel discovers some of the payoffs, and perils, of being a fiercely independent researcher.
title: Far from the frontier

author: Erika Check
description: For years it was assumed that tiny differences in our genetic make-up gave us our individual traits. Now it seems that those characteristics are caused by rearrangements of large chunks of our DNA — variations that could be the key to understanding disease. Erika Check investigates.
title: Patchwork people

author: Jenny Hogan
description: Biologists, planetary scientists and engineers have gathered in southern Spain to test a robotic drill. They hope some day to probe for life beneath the surface of Mars. Jenny Hogan investigates.
title: Life at the cutting edge

author: Simon Frantz
description: Forget drugs carefully designed to hit one particular molecule — a better way of treating complex diseases such as cancer may be to aim for several targets at once, says Simon Frantz.
title: Playing dirty

author: Emma Marris
description: Everyone knows about the Amazon rainforest, but Brazil's tropical savannah is arguably under greater threat. Emma Marris visits a testing ground for future conservation strategies.
title: The forgotten ecosystem

author: Alison Abbott
description: With a mathematician's logic and the perfectionism of a concert pianist, Nikos Logothetis is making waves in cognitive neuroscience — and putting the German town of Tübingen on the scientific map. Alison Abbott pays him a visit.
title: The maestro of minds

author: Jane Qiu
description: The Arctic is a unique testing ground for studying how birds navigate long distances. Jane Qiu catches up with an expedition to unravel the signals that help birds on their migrations.
title: Flight of the navigators

author: David Cyranoski
description: Thousands of patients are queueing to be treated by Hongyun Huang at his Beijing clinic. But no Western journal editor seems willing to publish his research. David Cyranoski talks to the neurosurgeon whose global reputation among the ailing hasn't swayed his peers.
title: Paper chase

author: Emma Marris
description: The friction that arises when a scientific society aims both to serve its members and stay commercially competitive is generating heat within the American Chemical Society. Emma Marris takes the society's temperature.
title: Chemical reaction

author: Jeff Kanipe
description: With one ageing telescope in space, and another mired in construction troubles on Earth, Matt Mountain has a tough job to do. Jeff Kanipe meets the new custodian of everyone's favourite space telescope.
title: Mountain at the top

author: Robert Cooke
description: Marine scientists are getting ready for their newest tool, a versatile robot submersible that can travel into the oceans' deepest abyss. Robert Cooke visits the Massachusetts lab where the future of deep-sea exploration is taking shape.
title: Back to the bottom

author: Lucy Odling-Smee
description: Approaches to conservation that seek to protect the most endangered species have had only mixed success. Is it time to move away from biodiversity ‘hotspots’, and stress the economic value of ecosystems? Lucy Odling-Smee investigates.
title: Dollars and sense

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: This month, as most researchers gear up to teach, two scientists are heading into the classroom to learn. Geoff Brumfiel asks why a physicist would want to enrol in biology lessons.
title: Back to school

author: Erika Check
description: Two researchers survived the worst of Hurricane Katrina, caring for sick patients in a flooded hospital. Erika Check hears of their harrowing experience.
title: Left behind

author: Heike Langenberg
description: Earth's climate depends strongly on clouds. But what really goes on within these layered structures? Heike Langenberg reports on two satellites that aim to find out.
title: Inside information

author: Rex Dalton
description: George Sugihara has gone from an academic career in biological oceanography to the world of high finance, and back again. Now he is applying the lessons he learned in business to the conservation of fish stocks. Rex Dalton reports.
title: Fishy futures

author: Jessica Marshall
description: The creaking infrastructure of Indonesia's capital is overwhelmed by people, vehicles and pollution. As urbanization gathers pace across the developing world, Jessica Marshall visits Jakarta to witness its stomach-churning consequences.
title: Megacity, mega mess...

author: Erika Check
description: Tackling the legal and ethical minefield associated with human embryonic stem-cell research is not for the faint-hearted. Erika Check meets one man who is relishing the challenge.
title: The rocky road to success

author: Rex Dalton
description: Sightings of the ivory-billed woodpecker, a bird believed extinct for 50 years, have fired the public's imagination. But is it really alive? Rex Dalton joins the team trying to save this elusive bird.
title: A wing and a prayer

author: Carina Dennis
description: The chimp was a great start. But the genomes of our other primate relatives will help to reveal a whole lot more, says Carina Dennis.
title: Branching out

author: Alexandra Witze
description: At first it was just an unusual, geeky hobby. But by combining their twin passions of chemistry and history, Jim and Jenny Marshall are now running an acclaimed project in science education. Alexandra Witze reports.
title: In their element

author: Meredith Wadman
description: Wound an embryo and it heals perfectly, with no scars. Can we teach adult wounds the same trick, asks Meredith Wadman.
title: The healing touch

author: Philip Ball
description: Is there any fundamental reason to be fixated on water as the universal elixir of life? Philip Ball investigates.
title: Seeking the solution

author: Emma Marris
description: Cindy Lee Van Dover likes nothing better than to be on the ocean floor. Emma Marris meets the unconventional biologist who has devoted her life to studying the exotic ecosystems of the deep.
title: The life aquatic

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: Preparing astronauts for a journey to the red planet has become NASA's research priority for the International Space Station. But such experiments will need more than the skeleton crew now running the station. Tony Reichhardt reports.
title: Testing times

author: John Whitfield
description: Can the behaviour of complex systems from cells to planetary climates be explained by the idea that they're driven to produce the maximum amount of disorder? John Whitfield investigates.
title: Order out of chaos

author: Claire Ainsworth
description: Far from being mere DNA delivery boys, it's now becoming clear that sperm also ship a complex cargo of RNA and proteins that may be crucial for an embryo's early development. Claire Ainsworth reports.
title: The secret life of sperm

author: David Cyranoski
description: Singapore's impressive advances in biomedicine are driven by the energetic personality of Philip Yeo. David Cyranoski meets a man who just can’t stand still.
title: An irresistible force

author: Laura Bonetta
description: Many scientists continue to run productive and innovative research programmes well beyond typical retirement age. But in many countries, tough retirement laws make staying in the lab a challenge. Laura Bonetta reports.
title: Breaking the age barrier

author: David Cyranoski
description: While other Asian tigers are roaring ahead in biotechnology, Malaysia's BioValley is going nowhere fast. David Cyranoski asks what went wrong.
title: The valley of ghosts

author: Amanda Haag
description: In 2015, Pluto will welcome its first visitor, a robot named New Horizons. Amanda Haag meets the planetary scientist who nursed the mission through its darkest days.
title: A man with a mission

author: Sarah Tomlin
description: Can mathematicians learn from the narrative approaches of the writers who popularize and dramatize their work? Sarah Tomlin is on the story.
title: What's the plot?

author: Emma Marris
description: As spokesman for America's scientific élite, Ralph Cicerone will have to do some tough talking in Washington. Emma Marris asks him how he'll ensure that politicians will listen to the science.
title: In defence of data

author: Phyllida Brown
description: After centuries of playing second fiddle to the blood system, our lymphatic circulation is coming into its own as a key player in diseases ranging from cancer to asthma. Phyllida Brown reports.
title: Unlocking the drains

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: For 50 years, physicists have been promising that power from nuclear fusion is imminent. Now they are poised to build an experiment that could vindicate their views. But will the machine work? Geoff Brumfiel investigates.
title: Just around the corner

author: Jim Giles
description: Cuba's socialist science policies are producing top-notch research from scant economic resources. But, as Jim Giles reports, they have harsh consequences for scientists who do not fit in with government priorities.
title: ¿Vive la revolución?

author: Carina Dennis
description: Surgeon Fiona Wood has pioneered a controversial treatment to reduce scarring in burns victims. Carina Dennis finds out how she counters her critics.
title: Hard graft

author: Alison Abbot
description: After a low-key existence for more than 50 years, Germany's Lindau meetings have opened their doors to the world. Alison Abbott joined 44 Nobel laureates as they mingled with young scientists.
title: Close encounters

author: Naomi Lubick
description: An ambitious international project to unite the planet's Earth-observing systems is under way. But getting everyone on board is no easy task, says Naomi Lubick.
title: Something to watch over us

author: Alison Abbott
description: Electrodes implanted in the brain could transform the lives of psychiatric patients. Alison Abbott watched an operation to release a man from his obsessive thoughts.
title: Deep in thought

author: Rex Dalton
description: Thanks to the influence of a powerful US senator, more than $120 million has been pumped into research on Alaska's endangered Steller sea lions in just four years. Rex Dalton asks what we've learned.
title: Is this any way to save a species?

author: Declan Butler
description: Record-keeping in the lab has stayed unchanged for hundreds of years, but today's experiments are putting huge pressure on the old ways. Declan Butler weighs up the pros and cons of electronic alternatives to that dog-eared notebook.
title: A new leaf

author: Trisha Gura
description: Experts in neuroscience, computing and education are coming together in a massive effort to put the way in which children are taught on a sounder scientific footing. Trisha Gura profiles this ambitious — some might say foolhardy — initiative.
title: Big plans for little brains

author: Peter Aldhous
description: The economic miracle that is transforming the world's most populous nation is threatened by energy shortages and rising pollution. It also risks plunging the planet's climate into chaos. Peter Aldhous reports.
title: China's burning ambition

author: Helen Pilcher
description: It was cold and clammy, but it changed the rules of life for ever. Helen Pilcher goes in search of the ancestor of all animals.
title: Back to our roots

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: Dalton Conley is an award-winning researcher who works on the politically charged issues of race, gender and class. He tells Tony Reichhardt why he wants to stress the ‘science’ in the social sciences.
title: Harder than Rocket Science

author: Amanda Haag
description: Are research expeditions to far-flung destinations as glamorous as they sound? Amanda Haag joins a few research novices who gave up their holidays for science.
title: A trip of a lifetime

author: Catherine Zandonella
description: Treatments that use stem cells to replace damaged or diseased tissues are thought to lie many years away. But the cells might find other clinical applications in the near future, says Catherine Zandonella.
title: The first wave

author: Duncan Graham-Rowe
description: Western conservation biologists working in Myanmar have been accused of colluding with a brutal military regime — charges they deny. Duncan Graham-Rowe reports from this pariah state.
title: Under the gun

author: Kendall Powell
description: Do US high schools dedicated to science generate future academics or burnt-out whiz kids? Kendall Powell catches up with some of the first pupils to graduate from ‘nerd school’.
title: Hothouse High

author: Nicola Jones
description: Twelve women have taken to bed for two months in the name of space research. Nicola Jones joins them for a few days, and asks what physiologists hope to learn from this marathon lie-in.
title: Lie back and think of science

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: In the world of billion-dollar particle physics, one lab is taking an enormous gamble on its future. Geoff Brumfiel takes a look at Fermilab's hopes to host the next big machine.
title: High-risk physics

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Siberia's vast forests absorb huge quantities of carbon from the atmosphere. But how much, and will they continue to do so in a warming world? Quirin Schiermeier speaks to the carbon accountants.
title: That sinking feeling

author: Jessica Ebert
description: Scientific research can be tricky at the best of times, but people with disabilities face additional challenges both in the lab and when dealing with data. Jessica Ebert meets the researchers who are building their own customized solutions to overcome these problems.
title: Access all areas

author: Claire Ainsworth
description: A mysterious disease that causes children's brains to melt away is caused by errors in RNA translation. But biologists are realizing that this horrifying condition could shed light on more common problems. Claire Ainsworth reports.
title: Lost in translation

author: Alison Abbott
description: Drugs that could lessen the death toll in a flu pandemic do exist. But global stockpiles are too small, and the countries at most immediate risk are among the worst prepared. Alison Abbott reports.
title: What's in the medicine cabinet?

author: Erika Check
description: We have the means to make a vaccine against pandemic flu. But quarrels over money, science and politics mean it could come too late, says Erika Check.
title: Is this our best shot?

author: Kendall Powell
description: Stem cells are engaged in constant crosstalk with their environment, biologists are fast realizing. So the emerging field of regenerative medicine is now wrestling with the ecological concept of the niche. Kendall Powell reports.
title: It's the ecology, stupid!

author: Alison Abbott
description: An Islamic theocracy ravaged by economic sanctions isn't an obvious place to seek a vibrant cognitive-neuroscience research group. Yet that's what Alison Abbott found on a recent trip to Iran.
title: The brains trust of Tehran

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: A new generation of planetary radar aims to look deeper than ever into some of the Solar System's most enduring mysteries. Tony Reichhardt gets ready for a trip to the interior.
title: Going underground

author: Mark Peplow
description: As construction on the world's largest optical telescope nears completion in Spain, the country's astronomers are gearing up for an expanded role on the global stage. Mark Peplow follows the preparations for first light.
title: Rising star

author: David Cyranoski
description: Companies and scientists in the West are keen to test their drugs in China, which is an important future market. But those running clinical trials need to be on their guard, says David Cyranoski.
title: Consenting adults? Not necessarily...

author: Roxanne Khamsi
description: Are wafers of silicon that support cells cultured from vital organs the future of drug testing and toxicology? Roxanne Khamsi talks to the pioneers creating model animals — and humans — on a chip.
title: Meet the stripped down rat

author: Duncan Graham-Rowe
description: Growing numbers of people are being implanted with electronic devices that can automatically restart a failing heart. But have the risks and benefits been adequately assessed? Duncan Graham-Rowe investigates.
title: Hotwire my heart

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: From meeting the Dalai Lama to national media star, Anton Zeilinger is on a mission to bring physics to a wider audience. Quirin Schiermeier listens in.
title: The philosopher of photons

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: The intelligent-design movement is a small but growing force on US university campuses. For some it bridges the gap between science and faith, for others it goes beyond the pale. Geoff Brumfiel meets the movement's vanguard.
title: Who has designs on your students' minds?

author: Helen Pearson
description: Digital photography and image-manipulation software allow biologists to tweak their data as never before. But there's a fine line between acceptable enhancements and scientific misconduct. Helen Pearson investigates.
title: CSI: cell biology

author: Jonathan Knight
description: A steady stream of mechanical animals is marching out of the lab into the field. Jonathan Knight tunes in to see how these motorized models can expose what makes real creatures behave the way they do.
title: When robots go wild

author: Alison Abbott
description: When a magician uses science to present his tricks, the effects are seductive. Alison Abbott takes a masterclass in sorcery.
title: Science as illusion

author: Jim Giles
description: Dust clouds can cool the Earth and halt hurricanes. But the world's biggest dust source was until recently a war zone. Jim Giles joins one of the few research teams to make the trip.
title: The dustiest place on Earth

author: Peter Aldhous
description: Deadly tropical infections that kill within 48 hours don't usually go unnoticed. But one killer has been largely ignored for decades. Now, thanks to worries about bioterror, it is being taken more seriously. Peter Aldhous reports.
title: Melioidosis? Never heard of it...

author: Peter Aldhous
description: California's voters have authorized the spending of $3 billion over the next decade on stem-cell research. But will this bonanza bring threats as well as opportunities? Peter Aldhous weighs the hopes and fears.
title: After the gold rush

author: Meredith Wadman
description: The past year has seen a beleaguered Food and Drug Administration publicly denounced as unable to protect the US public. As the political pressure mounts, Meredith Wadman joins the agency's hunt for a remedy to its ills.
title: The safety catch

author: Simon Frantz
description: Why do current safety systems sometimes fail to notice that approved drugs are causing serious adverse effects? And can surveillance methods be improved? Simon Frantz investigates.
title: Chasing shadows

author: Karen Fox
description: In 1995, scientists created the first ultracold quantum gas and to their surprise launched a new scientific field. Ten years on and its chilly revelations are attracting a growing number of physicists. Karen Fox joins the party.
title: Some like it cold

author: Rex Dalton
description: The scientists who discovered a new species of human in Indonesia last year are now back, looking for the bones that will flesh out their theories. Rex Dalton joins them.
title: Looking for the ancestors

author: Sharon Levy
description: Grenada's monkeys have thrived despite a huge degree of inbreeding. But now they face a new genetic bottleneck in the wake of Hurricane Ivan. Sharon Levy investigates.
title: Die hard

author: Erika Check
description: The sequence of the ‘feminine’ X chromosome is a prime hunting ground for geneticists interested in the evolution of the cognitive and cultural sophistication that defines the human species. Erika Check reports.
title: The X factor

author: Peter Aldhous
description: Dora Akunyili has spent the past four years facing down corruption and tackling Nigeria's rampant problems with fake drugs. This crusade has been phenomenally successful, but has placed Akunyili's life in danger. Peter Aldhous caught up with her on a recent trip to the United States.
title: In the line of fire

author: Peter Aldhous
description: Across the developing world, people are dying after being peddled fake pharmaceuticals. Peter Aldhous reports from southeast Asia, where scientists, doctors and regulators battle against organized crime.
title: Murder by medicine

author: Emma Marris
description: The United States has a settled arrangement for distributing its research budget around the country, and the same states have dominated it for decades. But, as Emma Marris discovers in Florida, the have-nots have had enough.
title: Upstart states

author: Haim Watzman
description: They were highly prized artefacts with inscriptions that dated back to biblical times. The only problem was they were fake. Haim Watzman unearths the authentication work that has rocked Israel's archaeology community.
title: Reality check

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: A small budget and big dreams make for a heady mix. But solar-sail pioneer Lou Friedman is ready for anything as spacecraft Cosmos 1 prepares to take on the Sun and the space agencies. Tony Reichhardt reports.
title: Setting sail for history

author: Alison Abbott
description: Just how proteins jostle around in the fatty membrane that surrounds every living cell has been a source of debate for decades. Now one researcher is using an ultra-high-speed camera to watch this dance in unprecedented detail — but that hasn't stopped the arguments. Alison Abbott investigates.
title: Hopping fences

author: Peter Aldhous
description: It was invented by a healer familiar with the horrors of opiate addiction, and refined by Vietnam's leading chemistry lab. Can this novel herbal cocktail ease withdrawal and reduce drug cravings? Peter Aldhous investigates.
title: Cold turkey, Vietnamese style

author: Amanda Haag
description: The fatty bones of dead whales provide rich pickings for creatures on the sea floor. Amanda Haag meets the scientists who go to extreme and unpleasant lengths to study the unique ecosystems on these corpses.
title: Whale fall

author: Alison Abbott
description: A few French scientists are bringing astronomy to captive audiences, such as the terminally ill and the incarcerated. Alison Abbott joined a group of convicted murderers to learn about gravity.
title: Prison talk

author: Ehsan Masood
description: Pakistan's traditional ways have blocked many women's careers in science. But, as Ehsan Masood discovers, women are now fighting for their rights, both in life and in research.
title: Women at work

author: Rex Dalton
description: Mexican scientists now have the skills and technology to study their backlog of ancient bones. As this treasure trove begins to yield its secrets, Rex Dalton finds local scientists hoping to unravel the mysteries of the earliest settlers of America.
title: Skeleton keys

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Quirin Schiermeier travels to Sri Lanka with a team of scientists in the wake of last month's tsunami. Together with locals they search through the damage for clues of where the wave hit hardest.
title: On the trail of destruction

author: Helen Pearson
description: Since he took over as Harvard president in 2001, Larry Summers' style and vision have divided the university. As his plans for expansion step up a gear, Summers tells Helen Pearson why it is time for Cambridge to face up to the need for change.
title: The premier division

author: Alison Abbott
description: Exercise is good for you, or so we always thought. But, as Alison Abbott learns, your genes don't always cooperate.
title: All pain, no gain?

author: Federica Castellani
description: Cave paintings and catacomb walls around Europe are decaying under microbial attack. Are nightclub lights and designer chemicals the answer? Federica Castellani finds out.
title: The film crew

author: Peter Aldhous
description: Having suffered heavily from avian influenza in 2004, Vietnam might now be brewing the next human flu pandemic. Yet, as Peter Aldhous discovers, local researchers don't have the resources to investigate the risk properly.
title: Vietnam's war on flu

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: So far, string theory has defied experiments, but Nima Arkani-Hamed thinks he has found a way to put the idea to the test. Geoff Brumfiel finds out how.
title: In search of hidden dimensions

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: The electronic behaviour of some forms of matter doesn't match theory. Geoff Brumfiel meets Senthil Todadri, a man who wants to change our view of how electrons behave.
title: Can electrons do the splits?

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Martin Bojowald is on a journey back in time to see what happened during the Big Bang. Quirin Schiermeier tags along for the ride.
title: The long-distance thinker

author: Haim Watzman
description: Growing up on Einstein Street in Haifa, Israel, Dorit Aharonov was perhaps destined to study physics. But she pursued other interests before finally settling on quantum computation. Haim Watzman reports.
title: A theorist of errors

author: Alison Abbott
description: Western science owes much to Islam's golden age — a debt that is often forgotten. To help redress the balance, Fuat Sezgin has reconstructed a host of scientific treasures using ancient Arabic texts. Alison Abbott reports.
title: Rebuilding the past

author: Peter Aldhous
description: Cane toads are infamous for wreaking havoc on Australian ecosystems. But, as Peter Aldhous discovers, we're only now about to learn whether their fearsome reputation is deserved.
title: The toads are coming!

author: Jonathan Knight
description: Many religious leaders find themselves at odds with science, but the head of Tibetan Buddhism is a notable exception. Jonathan Knight meets a neurologist whose audience with the Dalai Lama helped to explain why.
title: Buddhism on the brain

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: Embryonic stem-cell research is putting fresh strain on the already fractious relationship between science and religion. TonyReichhardt explores how faith is shaping the ever-changing landscape of bioethics.
title: Studies of faith

author: Erika Check
description: Bad news travels fastest. Or so the scientists fighting disease hope. Since 1994, ProMED-mail has been reporting outbreaks as soon as they happen. Erika Check meets the team behind the 24-hour service.
title: Dispatches from the front line

author: Erika Check
description: Resources are shifting from small labs led by one researcher to large teams with expensive equipment. But has the rise of big biology gone too far? Erika Check investigates.
title: David versus Goliath

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: The global spread of nuclear weapons is once again a major headache for world leaders. Geoff Brumfiel reports on efforts to put the genie back in the bottle.
title: We have the technology

author: Jim Giles
description: Benoit Mandelbrot is one of the twentieth century's best known mathematicians. So why, in the twilight of an extraordinary academic career, is he still angry with many of his colleagues? Jim Giles investigates.
title: Father of fractals

author: Michael Hopkin
description: Companies are already swapping money for the right to emit more pollution, and cashing in on projects designed to suck up greenhouse gases. As this market booms, will it actually help to cut down on emissions? Michael Hopkin reports.
title: The carbon game

author: Carina Dennis
description: A strange Australian mole has eluded scientific study for more than a century. Now biologists are teaming up with Aboriginal trackers to unearth the secrets of the itjaritjari. Carina Dennis checks on their progress.
title: A mole in hand...

author: Peter Aldhous
description: Vast tracts of Indonesia's peat swamps have been drained in a misguided attempt to turn them into rice plantations. Now the landscape burns every year, belching smoke and hastening global warming. Peter Aldhous investigates.
title: Borneo is burning

author: Helen Pilcher
description: Recent studies are pointing the way for new uses of an ancient treatment — leeches. Helen Pilcher wades in to find out how these creatures could help the arthritic.
title: Stuck on you

author: Henry Nicholls
description: Can an ambitious plan to protect unique marine habitats in the open ocean turn the tide of destruction? Henry Nicholls plunges in.
title: Sink or swim

author: Tony Reichhardt
description: The gamma rays spat out by dying stars last an instant. Tony Reichhardt reports on the fast-response satellite that hopes to capture them.
title: Bagging bursts, swiftly

author: David Cyranoski
description: Earthquake researchers in the United States have long shunned the word ‘prediction’. But, thanks to improved data and a change in public perception, cracks are beginning to appear in their resolve. David Cyranoski tracks the debate.
title: A seismic shift in thinking

author: Martin Leeb
description: Antibiotics are failing and drug companies have all but stopped developing new ones. Will conquered diseases come back to haunt us? Martin Leeb examines one plan to avert the crisis.
title: A shot in the arm

author: Carina Dennis
description: Employing genetic diagnosis to avoid having a baby with a disability is controversial enough. But a minority of deaf people would consider testing to ensure that they had a deaf child. Carina Dennis finds out why.
title: Deaf by design

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: The next generation of Antarctic research stations is now being designed and built. Quirin Schiermeier reveals the problems that architects, engineers and inhabitants must overcome in the Pole's unforgiving conditions.
title: Cold comfort

author: Karl Ziemelis
description: With the rules of the game changing before every season, Formula 1 engineers often have a matter of weeks to redesign their car before it is tested on the track. Karl Ziemelis and Charles Wenz join the race to the start line.
title: Science in the FAST LANE

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: One of Saddam Hussein's senior weapons designers tells Geoff Brumfiel of his past, and of his hopes for a new career.
title: Rocket man

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: The production of silicon chips is big business, but with success have come environmental concerns. Geoff Brumfiel meets the people helping the industry to clean up its act.
title: Chipping in

author: Philip Ball
description: Genetic engineering is old hat. Biologists are now synthesizing genomes, altering the genetic code and contemplating new life forms. Is it time to think about the risks? Philip Ball asks the experts.
title: Starting from scratch

author: Helen Pearson
description: Testosterone therapy jacks up vigour, sex drive and mental acuity — or so proponents claim. But are those who experiment with this potent sex hormone gambling with their health? Helen Pearson investigates.
title: A dangerous elixir?

author: Rex Dalton
description: Plans to push tuna farms out into open waters off the coast of the United States are raising an environmental alarm. Rex Dalton discovers the kind of problems these offshore ranches might cause.
title: Fishing for trouble

author: Philip Ball
description: Enzymes are well known for speeding up reactions. But have they evolved to use quantum mechanics to exert their effects? Philip Ball meets the researchers who are trying to find out.
title: By chance, or by design?

author: Mark Schrope
description: Every summer, Florida plays host to researchers who fire rockets at the sky to create lightning. And having captured the bolts, the group has found something shocking, as Mark Schrope finds out.
title: The bolt catchers

author: Erika Check
description: They were hailed as wonder drugs to banish depression, but may cause suicidal thoughts in some children. Companies are under attack for failing to publish these data. Erika Check considers the science behind a scandal.
title: Bitter pills

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Only Russia can rescue the global agreement on climate change. So why aren't Russian climate scientists speaking up? Quirin Schiermeier and Bryon MacWilliams report from Moscow.
title: Crunch time for Kyoto

author: Sarah Tomlin
description: Piers Coleman is a theoretical physicist, his brother Jaz a musician with an unusual pedigree. Together, they want to break down boundaries between science and the arts. Sarah Tomlin attends their latest concert.
title: Brothers in art

author: David Cyranoski
description: Hiroaki Serizawa's promising US academic career was ruined when a favour to a friend led to him being charged with economic espionage on behalf of Japan. He tells his story to David Cyranoski.
title: The accidental spy

author: Laura Nelson
description: Ever woken up with the answer to a problem that had seemed insoluble the night before, or able to perform a task that had previously taxed your skills? We may soon know why, says Laura Nelson.
title: While you were sleeping

author: Michael Hopkin
description: Archaeologists have failed to learn the secrets of Mexico's largest ancient monument. Particle physicists might save the day, says Michael Hopkin.
title: Pyramid power

author: Alison Abbott
description: CERN, the centre for particle physics in Europe, has been smashing its way through the subatomic world for the past 50 years. Alison Abbott finds out what's in store for the future.
title: The show goes on

author: Quirin Schiermeier
description: Did a great flood once surge into the Black Sea, forming the basis of a Biblical tale? Quirin Schiermeier investigates a computer model that has added weight to the idea.
title: Noah's flood

author: Jonathan Knight
description: Last month, a handful of scientists who have toyed with the idea of writing for the movies were given a masterclass by Tinseltown's finest. Jonathan Knight joined them.
title: Hollywood or bust

author: Nicola Jones
description: Special report on the Olympics
title: To the edge... and over

author: Martin Leeb
description: This year's Olympics will take place in Athens, a city renowned for its hot, humid summers and stifling air pollution. Martin Leeb discovers how the athletes plan to overcome the hurdle of these tough conditions.
title: Gasping for victory

author: Alison Abbott
description: Olympic athletes are on the edge of normal physiology, finds Alison Abbott.
title: A breed apart

author: Jim Giles
description: Athletes' punishing schedules push their bodies to the limit. But what happens if they go too far? Jim Giles finds out.
title: The medals and the damage done

author: Laura Spinney
description: Some athletes diagnosed with a genetic heart condition are banned from competitive sport. Laura Spinney discovers how they are fighting for the right to run the risk of death.
title: Heart-stopping action

author: Geoff Brumfiel
description: Physicists agree that experiments at the Brookhaven atom collider have created a new form of matter. But theorists and experimentalists are still arguing about what to call it. Geoff Brumfiel investigates.
title: What's in a name?

author: Rex Dalton
description: Medical geneticists and isolated Native American communities afflicted by inherited diseases should have much to gain from working together. But the relationship can go sour, as Rex Dalton finds out.
title: When two tribes go to war

author: Carina Dennis
